The sharp SCRAPING of the jagged blade against skin is th hear. VALLON cuts himself similarly on the left cheek, then han ceremoniously to a BOY standing beside him. The boy, no m years old, looks at VALLON worshipfully, keen eyes shinin excitement. He starts to wipe the razor blade on the bott

No. Never. The blood stays on the blade, son. He hands the boy a dark red velvet pouch. Very carefully, as AMSTERDAM, wraps the razor up, hands it back to his fa From the shadows, VALLON now raises a long pole with a be crucifix mounted on the end, then holds his free hand out Amsterdam squeezes tight. VALLON nods toward the door. Amsterdam pulls it open. Out hallway. We hear SOUNDS that might be animal or human. MUSIC begins: a steady, driving cadence somewhere between hymn.

VALLON strides in long measured steps. Amsterdam has trou with him. They are walking down a long corridor that's like a tunne LIGHT stain the darkness. Sometimes Amsterdam glimpses a from the gloom. Once or twice he almost stumbles over a B across his path.

Another room, even smaller. The only decoration is a biza a Madonna and child painted on the wall. A beefy man picks up a home-made PIKE, its iron tip sharp point. He is smiling. The grin is huge, but cockeyed. It half of his face. The grotesque, unending grin is the res paralysis, and has given him a nickname: HAPPY JACK MULRA Jack lifts the pike carefully, then takes a candle from t down over a wooden cage full of rabbits. He slowly moves and forth across the cage top. Wax falls on the cage, spl unlucky rabbit. Jack thrusts the pike between the wooden bars, impaling t He pulls the pike from the cage and leaves.
Jack falls into step beside VALLON and Amsterdam. He hold the dead rabbit high, next to VALLON's cross.
Did you bring the boy for a charm, Priest?

No, Jack. For a baptism. Now a WOMAN joins them. She's dressed in man's clothes, h by suspenders. She wears a set of IRON CLAWS. MUSIC builds, growing more insistent and more ominous. Now a figure looms before them. Over his street clothes, wears a rig of home-made armor made from fracgments of st chain and bits of leather. He carries a battle-axe as lig were a twig.

We'll send a few across the river today, Priest. He joins the procession. Another woman, as tough as the f again as large, and several more men, all armed with impl destruction, fall in beside him. Their faces are marked w Vallan's, or covered with ritual markings made with paint The group grows ever larger and more forbidding. occasion around them in the tunnel and scamper out of their way li frightened in a burrow.

Vast and dank, like a cavern. We start CLOSE on... ... the body of a dead rat being filled with some pieces Then a little WIDER to reveal: an eager boy, SHANG DRAPER age as Amsterdam. He drops the last few pieces of lead in the rat, then sews it closed. He hefts the animal by the as he stands up. He is near a primitive forge where a half-drunk SLACKSMIT weapons into shape and distributes them to OTHER MEN and is covered with bits of lead and steel, which Shang has b into his rat. Shang FOLLOWS the crowd of men and women with their weapo see this room full. It is huge: the main room of the Old with families huddled together for warmth and comfort, or and women, together or separately, drunk or passed out. T animals in a pit. There are sticks of furniture jammed in more often, arranged at angles in the middle of the room enclaves where the ancient brewery machinery forms irregu Above Shang's head, VALLON and his gang walk across a pla spans the room a hundred feet beneath them. Armed men and Brewery are climbing a rope ladder to join them. Shang SC them. The men and women from the Brewery fall in behind VALLON the lead. Shang SPOTS someone near his own age toward the Amsterdam. He presses through the crowd like a hunting do
What's the fight?
The Dead Rabbits against the Native Americans, same as ev be settled today.
Are you Native or Rabbit?
(points to rabbit on pike) What do you think?
Looks alright. I'll stand by you, then.
The group now turns down the last corridor, as dim and lo In the distance, there's a faint glimmer of light and the (MONK EASTMAN). VALLON stops near the door.
I don't know you.
(lightly) I suppose there's to be a fight. VALLON catches the heavy Celtic inflection in the man's v
Derry?
Donnegal. Name's Monk Eastman.
And you want to fight, Mr. Eastman?
lf there's money in it.
Fight for the Natives. They have a proper war chest.
Well, I might at that. But I thought I'd ask you first, s not quite a Native American myself.
Let's see your skills, and we'll talk of payment later.

Fine. But if you like what you see, pay me double. Monk turns to the door with the grace of a dancer and del SHATTERING kick, sending it flying off its hinges. Clear streams in, and we see Monk Eastman plain for the first t in stature and girth, wearing a small DERBY that intentio head look even bigger.
(as the door splinters settle) Stand with us then.

WINTER WIND blows across a scene as strange and bleak as VALLON, carrying his cross high, steps through the doorwa slowly follow VALLON out of the building, which is three maybe a block long. A dilapidated sign identifies it as t Brewery. It is the tallest structure in the midst of low, squalid ALLEYS as narrow as a snakels back, and DIRT STREETS fill and filthy snow. A few PIGS wander forlornly about, rooti WASH hangs stiff, in the middle of the square, from a pec erected to some forgotten war hero. The Brewery occupies one side of a SQUARE surrounded by s and a couple of collapsed wooden sidewalks. If this place anything at all, it's a horrible hybrid of London's Limeh pioneer town in the American West whose best days have lo never came at all. VALLON stands still, staring across the square past the m battalion of irregulars waits for his signal. Now... very, very slowly...from around both sides of the ANOTHER GANG, in size the same as VALLON's, men and women Visigoths with HOMEMADE WEAPONS: knives, pitchforks, buil bricks, boards with sharp nails protruding from the ends. this second group is dressed in a long DUSTER which reach Several MEN in front of the group sport dusters made of l

Bill Poole! on whose challenge are we assembled? A MAN in a leather duster (BILL THE BUTCHER) steps forwar lean and fierce. And then there are his eyes. They do not real. The other is a huge, bulging PEARL upon which has b instead of a pupil, a full-color portrait of the AMERICAN On the side of the square, arranged to get a good view of combat, is a group of STREET KIDS, girls and boys, none o They talk and laugh excitedly among themselves, picking t favorites among the gangs as if the warriors were players
On the challenge of the Native Americans, to settle for g holds sway.
Bene.
By the ancient laws of combat, we offer our bodies to the warriors who have gone before us. Valor is avid for glory our wounds.
But this time can you bear to look on the glory when it c you see it clear with your single eye?
Whoever fights untouched in battle has skill, but the war wounded has been touched by God.
It wasn't God who touched your eye.
It was God gave me guidance. Will you be able to look on like a gladiator, and not look away? No honorable man tur his death.
I don't expect a death blow from your hand, Butcher. Let'
There is another matter.
Say it out and quick, before spring gets here.
No Native American Warrior will dishonor himself with the halt and maimed.
So?

So we would like to know whether Squire Jack Mulraney of can smile out of both sides of his face. A pause of a single second. Then HAPPY JACK takes the dea tip of his pike and hurls it across the square. It lands BUTCHER's feet. In a flash, BILL THE BUTCHER opens his coat. Inside, on a carries a CLEAVER, a CARVING KNIFE and other instruments trade, all stained with blood and gristle. Now the MAN st him removes the broad BELT from around his coat. The bras sharpened to a point, the leather studded with glass. The gallery of Street Kids tenses for action: they are th VALLON reaches up to the CROSS, pulls off the top piece, underneath, a gleaming sword point. He folds the arms of like the blades of a jackknife.

Prepare to receive the Lord. And the air is full of screams and battle cries as the tw across Paradise Square into BATTLE. VALLON draws first blood. He impales a Native American on his cross and turns to fight again. Amsterdam and Shang exchange a glance of frightened, worr Then a Native American rushes at them, shouting for blood together. Amsterdam dives down in front of the man, sendi Shang BLUDGEONS the fallen warrior, using his lead-filled blackjack as Amsterdam kicks him savagely; the Native col unconscicus at their feet. Before the boys can thank one they are separaten by the SURGING GANGS all around them. BILL THE BUTCHER leaves his meat CLEAVER imbedded in the skull, then WADES through the combat as if shielded by a The gallery of Street Kids is thrilled by this display an CHEERS. VALLON BATTLES three Natives who come at him at once. Monk Eastman grabs a Native in his arms like a groom hugg raises his knee and brings the man crashing down across i spine like a Thanksgiving wishbone. The gallery of Street Kids is awed by this display of pow star in the making. The Rabbit Warrior in the home-made armor grins at an int lowers his battle-axe. The Native rushes as the Rabbit Warrior swings and SEPARATES the man from his legs A NATIVE WOMAN lowers her head and charges her Dead Rabbi delivering a shattering BUTT to his stomach. A NATIVE BOY holds a rusty old pistol, which he uses at p against several Rabbits. A RABBIT WOMAN flies into a Native, using her IRON FINGER GOUGE his face. The NATIVE with the deadly belt uses it to TEAR a piece o face. Amsterdam, beginning now to be overwhelmed by the hellish around in growing PANIC for his father. SHANG uses his lead-rat blackjack to clear an escape back Brewery. The Street Kids can tell he's trying to escape, him... ... as Shang's GRABBED from behind and pulled off his fee NATIVE. He THROWS the boy to the ground and pins him by h sword-sharp point of his wooden leg against Shang's throa
(desperate) I run with you! I'm one of you! Born a Native American fr five generations!

Yeah? Then you oughta be a red Indian. He pushes down. Shang starts to bleed. But now PEG LEG is the sudden SOUND of bells and whistles. He watches the BO the ground, then moves off him, making for the sound of t the BOY quaking. The SOUND grows louder as TWO HORSE-DRAWN CARTS full of b POLICE tear around the curve of a narrow thoroughfare and Square. The BELLS on the carts toll loudly and work magic. The fi The POLICE, all carrying clubs and wearing leather helmet wagons. There are several moments of ABSOLUTE SILENCE, broken onl the wind and the GROANS of the wounded. Then, as one, the Dead Rabbits and the Native Americans R together, hurtling stones and brandishing weapons. Even t get into the act, kicking and biting and generally having The gangs SWARM all over the police, driving them back. S climb back on the wagons and try to get away. The unlucky behind, dead on the ground. The GANGS cheer, jeer and continue to throw things at the POLICE. When the second wagon disappears from view, the G each other once again. Another brief moment of QUIET. The Street Kids settle bac spectator role. Then the GANGS go at each other with fres Amsterdam finally SEES his father and starts to PUSH his VALLON and BILL THE BUTCHER stand facing each other in th like two titans: then they rush at each other, joining wi fury. Shang, still blindly SWINGING his blackjack, makes his wa relative safety of the Brewery, his face stained with tea hits someone. The MAN turns, swats him down. Shang sprawl which is a SWAMP of mud and blood and dirty snow, and fin to face with a departed PEG LEG. Someone has removed his and driven it through his heart. Across the square, Amsterdam has reached his father in ti NATIVE AMERICAN sneaking up behind him. Amsterdam grabs a from a fallen warrior and uses it to hit the man a strong knees. The MAN falls, howling. AMSTERDAM HITS him again. And aga hysterical. VALLON and BILL THE BUTCHER keep fighting. Amsterdam sees look, that his father is in the fight of his life. He loo to help... ... sees a HATCHET lying by the body of the Rabbit he has senseless. He grabs it and runs forward, looking for an o the Butcher and his father... As the two combatants move, Amsterdam MOVES. Bobbing, wea falling back... looking for his chance... ... as Bill deals VALLON a blow that ROCKS him back and t balance... ...just as Amsterdam has made his move. He RUSHES forward FALLING, tries to turn but... ... too late. The boy's hatchet SLASHES his father in the falls to one knee, gestures frantically to the stunned Am away... ... and Bill is upon VALLON, SINKING his knife into his c screams and falls on his back, Bill kneeling over him. He enemy's eyes ... and VALLON's EYES LOCK ON HIS. For all h VALLON's eyes HOLD Bill ... he forces himself to look at terrible struggle... but VALLON will not look away. Amsterdam, hysterical, RUSHES at the Butcher. The Butcher by the arm, making him drop his hatchet.
You need a weapon? Use a knife. He puts the struggling boy's hand on the hilt of the knif Butcher sunk into his father's chest.
It makes a deeper cut. And, HIS HAND GUIDING THE BOY'S, he RAMS his knife deep i heart.
Say a benediction, Priest. VALLON bellows in agony. Amsterdam screams at the very sa cry mingling with his fatherls tearing through the air.

(to Amsterdam) Hold this close to mind, boy, should you ever think of go the Native Americans. Bill the Butcher rises and all around him, as if on some signal, the fighting subsides. A DEAD RABBIT sees the fal a battered brass HORN from his belt and sounds THREE NOTE sharp. As the notes fade away, the fighting stops complet

(announcing) Ears and noses will be trophies of the day. The Rabbits SCAMPER to collect their dead and wounded bef can get to them to slice off the battle souvenirs. But th corpses maimed. The Street Kids DISPERSE. The main battle Natives have clearly carried the day. The Rabbits file past Vallon, rorming a protective CIRCLE Amsterdam kneels at his side. Vallon tries to speak. Bloo throat.

Can't..can't cross the river... with steel through my hea Amsterdam looks around. None of the Rabbits makes a move. something he is meant to do himself. Amsterdam grabs the tortoise handle of the knife, PULLS o tries not to cry out. The knife does not move. Amsterdam tries again. He can't budge the knife. Vallon M wild, Amsterdam PULLS with all his strength. Vallon SCREA Amsterdam is pulling so hard he raises his father's back the ground. Still the knife will not move. Vallon passes Now, finally, someone steps forward: Monk Eastman. He lea Amsterdam, berserk with grief, pushes him away, turns bac and, with a last desperate pull, DRAWS the knife from his He throws it on the ground. Monk picks it up, wipes the b closes the knife and hands it to Amsterdam.
That's yours, rightfully. Now Monk leans over the lifeless body and reaches inside REMOVING some money.
And this is mine. Only what's owed. Use the rest for fune
No! He tries to shove Monk away from his father, when the Nat intervenes.

It's fair. Amsterdam, wild with shock and grief, turns back to his f takes what's owed him. Amsterdam bends over to KISS Vallo then on his left eye. The boy is just about to kiss his fatheros closed right e springs OPEN - Amsterdam jumps back despite himself. Vall a last moment of recognition.
Hon ...
No, Pa!
... honor me... think of me ... don't never look away. Vallon convulses and DIES. Amsterdam shakes him to revive
Take the body. Bring the boy. Several RABBITS take a step or two forward, but Amsterdam them, like an animal.
Come an, lad. Therels nothing to be done now.
Get away! Get away!

Leave him be. He's his to mourn. And the RABBITS turn away, going back to the Old Brewery the narrow streets. Now a few CITIZENS venture out into Paradise square. A co SCAVENGERS scoot about, looting bodies. Amsterdam stays in the center of the square unmoving, und solitary vigil over his father. A TITLE is superimposed across this scene:

The same afternoon. As the sun goes down, we have our fir (MATTE) at the low pale outlines of the city. The harbor is crowded with the high masts of sailing ship the island tip is the steeple of the city's tallest struc Church. The buildings of Wall Street are masses of concre streets surrounding them paved with cobblestones. Just ab district are the sloping buildings and rutted avenue of t The Old Brewery stands tall and forbidding over Paradise Above the Five Points, in the distance, we can glimpse so buildings. One wide street--Broadway--seems to run from t the island clear up into the woods just a few miles north The only SOUNDS are the lapping of the harbor water again creaking of masts in the winter WIND.
A closer view - The TITLE fades off. We see an imposing e edge of the harbor with a wooden sign identifying: "IMMIG

The sun has nearly set. A boy--about 10 years old--sits o Castle Garden dock, gazing down at the frozen Hudson. He make out his reflection in the dull sheen of the ice. His SIROCCO, and he watches himself with bewildered seriousne Abruptly, he reaches down and SMASHES through the ice wit SLOW MOTION, we watch the ice fragments drift apart in th each bearing away a REFLECTION of Johnnyls face, like pie
Where's your family, sonny? Johnny sees a POLICEMAN scrutinizing him.
(lilting brogue) My mother's just there. He gestures toward a ship, where MEN are unloading cargo. are lowering a thin pine COFFIN to dockside.
On the trip, her insides all broke up. She wasn't dead an others fighting for her bed.
And your father? Where's he, then?
I never knew him.
(taking Johnny's hand) We better see to you, then.
The Policeman leads an awed Johnny through the TEEMING st Points.

Where all those streets come together right ahead is the But most speak of the Five Points and mean anywhere betwe and the Bowery. Although the night's cold, the streets are jammed. WHORES carnival Gypsies sell themselves to any man sober enough SOUNDS of laughter and combat filter out from garish SALO Little Naples, the Hell Hole, the Egyptian Hall. In the midst of all this highlife are BEGGARS and the SIC charity, scrounging garbage in the street. An INDIGENT ba for a meager scrap of faod. A richly dressed WOMAN, ridin carriage, hides her eyes by raising a HUGE BOUQUET OF FLO her face.

Streets hereabouts are lively of an evening. The city com But there's places to put up a boy on his own. Three WOMEN, exquisitely costed, burst from the door of t Under the harsh glare of a nearby gas lamp, their faces a striking. Johnny STARES; there is something not right abo
And those? What are those?
Well, those. Those are, as you might say, a sort of... We SEE one of the women's faces, suddenly harsh under gas thickly caked make-up is a smiling TRANSVESTITE.
... sort of whatnot.
Say, policeman. I'll buy your bonny friend. The Policeman fetches the Transvestite a strong WHACK wit The Transvestite screams and falls ... and Johnny RUNS.
Hey! But Johnny's off, already lost in the mad street life.

A funeral chapel. Vallan's body lies in state. He is wearing his gang regal Dead Rabbits FILE PAST his coffin in solemn tribute. A WO and kisses the body. Happy Jack Mulraney holds Vallon's c has obviously inherited. As a disreputable looking Minist PRAYERS, Happy Jack whispers to a silent Amsterdam.
We passed the plate amongst ourselves. Come up with enoug all this, and carry you a while, too. He stuffs some money in Amsterdam's pocket.
Where will my father rest?
Potters Field, with everyone else.
My father won't be buried with everyone else. He'll lie s ground, facing east.
What difference where he faces?
He'll face east for the second coming of Christ.

Fine, son. When Jesus gets to the Battery you show Him th The Minister finishes the service. MR. CORNELIUS, a funer resembles one of his own customers, ushers in a WOMAN (MA lovely 10 year old GIRL (JENNY EVERDEKNE) by the hand. Th obviously drunk, the girl frightened.
Will you have music, entlegen
My daughter'11 do any song you like.
Not tonight, Maggie, we got... Monk Eastman interrupts from the Background.
How much?
Any ned in your pocket, sir. MONK hands MAGGIE some coins.
She sing sweet as she looks?
Pure celestial, sir. (to girl) Go on, Jenny. Jenny's voice is sweet as promised. The song she SINGS, h bawdy saloon song. Maggie cuts her off fast.
No, Jen, the other. Jenny starts to sing a HYMN. To avoid looking at the corp eyes rove all around the chapel until she SEES Amsterdam. straight at him until the hymn is over. And he does not t her.
Mr. Cornelius is about to escort Maggie and Jenny into an crowded with mourners when a smartly-dressed man (DANIEL gestures to him from the shadows.

Mr. Tweed would like a word, Mr. Cornelius. (Cornelius hesitates) Tweed of Tammany. At the mention of the name, Cornelius shoos Maggie and Je mourning room and shuts the door behind them. Then he giv full attention.
In your office. At your pleasure, of course.

As the door opens, we see a man gazing out the narrow win spectacle in the next building. He is in his late 20s, al fleshy but dressed with dash: WILLIAM TWEED... "BOSS" TWE bemused, almost schalarly interest in the goings-on next This mortuary is located next to a bordello, where the wi uncurtained and the energy and variety of the activities inside is astounding. Tweed finally TURNS as Killoran opens the door.
Mr. Cornelius. With a view like this I'm surprised the de peace.
Is there anything I can...
(interrupting) Yes. A favor.
Happy to serve, Mr. Tweed.
Excellent. Lend me something.
(puzzled) Oh, I don't know what I could ...
I believe in form and appearance, you see. Just like your believe in law, and the power of example. Our city is a l wilderness, sir. I'm asking you to help chasten it.
A matter of civic duty, then.
And civic pride. I want you to help me set an example. (smiles) I only need to borrow one of your clients.

Two native Americans open the door where Vallon is laid o Butcher STRIDES into the room. There is immediate TENSION, like an electric charge, as o stand in the doorway and crowd the hall stand while Bill coffin. He places a BLACK ROSE in Vallon's folded hands.

Tomorrow your cortege will cross Paradise Square, into te by the Native Americans. You will be permitted undisputed ways. That is our tribute. After that, any Rabbits wishin Native Americans and willing to swear blood loyalty will others will be dispatched. He starts out of the silent room, but STOPS when he sees looking at him with easy interest. Bill the Butcher STARES him down, but Monk's gaze never wavers.
I'll expect you first.
Me? Oh, I don't know. All that talk of blood loyalty make spill blood when the price is right. But blood for ceremo communion.
You saw us fight today. You know we can pay any price.
Not mine. Not now, and not any time after.
We'll see. Independence is a slippery thing. But being a that's dead dangerous. Bill brushes past Monk and leaves, followed by the NATIVE Now the RABBITS file out, with Monk among them.
Come on, boyo. I'll put you up tonight.
I'll do for myself, Jack.
You can't. (Amsterdam stares at him) There's no mistaking you're his son. Happy Jack leaves Amsterdam alone in the room. Now, by himself, sure of no one seeing, Amsterdam CRIES.
Mr. Cornelius is seated in his office, enjoying a late su looking out his window at the bordello activity across th at the door disturbs him: Amsterdam.
What's the cost to bury my father proud and proper?
For a plot, a headstone, hands to break the earth...
How much?
What are your current means? Amsterdam turns out his pockets, which contain Bill the B knife as well as the cash Happy Jack pressed on him. Corn all.
Of course you'll have to wait three days for a city permi may do for part.
No. Amsterdam takes the knife back from Cornelius.
That's owed another.

A grey day. Amsterdam stops in front of a window. He STRU scarf, trying to keep himself warm. His eye strays for a sees he is outside Mr. Cornelius' Establishment. Then he else.... .... his FATHER, propped up in a coffin, on public displa large sign beside the body: "The Dead End of Lawlessness. Crime. Tammany Means Justice." A sizeable CROWD is goggling at the body. Amsterdam BULLS the people to the street. He looks in the gutter, then lo Someone is watching him: Johnny. He's carrying an armful
Firewood? Amsterdam grabs the longest plank Johnny has.
It's a penny the load.
Later. He turns with the plank in his hand and starts to RUN bac crowd.

Hey! Johnny manages to GRAB the other end of the plank. But Am strong he YANKS him right along. The Crowd YELLS as it pa Amsterdam, who CHARGES through using the plank like a bat Johnny on the far end, born along by stubbornness and mom ... toward Mr. Cornelius' window. Amsterdam SHATTERS the Crowd SCATTERS in a blizzard of GLASS. Amsterdam stumbles into the window and against the coffin over, spilling Vallon's BODY, knocking the boy over. Amst himself up as Johnny stands frozen.
Help me. He starts to pull his fatherls body from the window.

Come on! Help me, goddamn it! In a daze, Johnny steps forward and HELPS Amsterdam pulls the street. Now: the SOUND of WHISTLES and WHEELS and RUNNING HORSES of POLICE arrives on the scene. Behind them, the Crowd re insults. The police RUN toward the window. Mr. Cornelius dithers a the crowd. Amsterdam and Johnny exchange a look. Then Johnny RUNS fo stays with the body... ... as the cops close in, SWINGING clubs. Amsterdam's gra couple of times. The Crowd yells. A COP swings his arm ba Amsterdam a good wallop... ... and someone grabs his arm: Bill The Butcher.
Easy, crusher. What's this all about?
Ask the boy.
I paid Cornelius for my father to rest in honor. He told on a permit, but he only wanted time to... BILL picks up the Tammany sign from the ground.
Make another Arrangement, looks like. For advertising. (to cop) Better go along. I'll see to all this.
The boy...
Take the little malefactor. The Cops YANK the wildly flailing Amsterdam to his feet a to their wagon. Bill The Butcher approaches Cornelius.
Give the boy what he paid for.

Amsterdam is HURLED into the police wagon. The door is lo He pulls himselt to his feet, looks out the tiny barred w ... Dead Rabbits join up in a rough funeral procession. S Vallon's body back into the coffin and place it onto Mr. funeral wagon. Monk Eastman LEAPS up onto the wagon and c lid tight. There are PEDDLERS everywhere. One dispenses drinks from samovar. A SAILOR hawks ships in a bottle, repeatedly sho advertisement: "Encourage the work of a landswamped sailo ARTIST offers to draw portraits of passersby. Funeral music is furnished by STREET MUSICIANS: a drummer player, and a horn player, with a couple of BUSKERS perfo for good measure. Mr. Cornelius takes the wagon reins and guides the horses square. The gang FOLLOWS solemnly behind. And across the square, the police wagon carrying Amsterda OFF in the opposite direction. He keeps looking out the t The funeral procession leaves the square and activity ret normal. Peddlers' CRIES once again fill the air. The Busk a snappier tune. SNOW begins to fall.

A huge, awful prison building modeled on an Egyptian maus Amsterdam--trying to hide his growing fear--waits on line PRISONERS, all of them older than he. At the head of the line, prisoners are being processed by couple of COPS. Each prisoner is asked several cursory qu told to strip. Every one of the men is SCARRED in some wa AMSTERDAM nears the front of the line. The MAN just ahead undresses. His left buttock is missing, and his back is c scars. A PRISONER behind Amsterdam WHISPERS loud enough f hear...
Ain't his first Tombs trip. ANSTERDAM steps up to the desk. The JAILER hardly takes n
What do they call you? And this is the first time in the film we have heard his
Amsterdam. The JAILER looks him over.
Your full name.
Vallon. The JAILER writes this down with a scratchy pen.
First name?
I told you.
(skeptical, resigned) Address?
Got none.
I'll put city. Now what's your age? (Amsterdam shrugs.) Maybe twelve. Got a family?
No more.
Well, where was they from when you had one?
(beat) City.
(writing) Disrobe. As Amsterdam obeys, the Jailer turns to the Cop in the le standing at his side.
What's the charge, Asbury?
Theft. Assault. Creating a ... The Jailer finishes writing. Amsterdam stands naked.
Through that door there. (lowers his voice) And don't stand too near no one else.

The largest, noisiest, gaudiest dive we have yet seen, fu with bawdy CUSTOMERS even at this late hour. Therels a lo and women stand three deep; lots of small tables; a dance stage on which four blowsy DANCING GIRLS are giving out w number titled "My Father's Teeth Were Plugged With Zinc." One end of the bar is entirely taken up by a huge woaden attached hose. BAR ATTENDANTS DUMP the unfinished content the open barrel top as a line of FAR GONE DRUNKS wait the hose. Maggie, Jenny's mother, is close to the front of th drunk, hanging on to a mush-faced HOODLUM. Two VISITORS watch. One has a pad and makes quick SKETCHE
Ought to be served in a trough, properly. Will you try so
Probably. What is it?
All-Sorts. It's made of all that's poured and not drunk, salvage that's spilt. Maggie GRABS the hose, staring at the Artist as she takes hand moves quickly an the page, SKETCHING her.

(to Maggie) Your health. She SPITS at him, insulted. The Artist steps forward, put All-Sorts from the hose into his glass, and toasts Maggie turns away.... ...as Johnny enters, dragging a large SACK across the cro a far door.

Johnny RUSHES toward a wooden pen in the center of the ro cries from the crowd of SPORTSMEN of "Hurry it up" and "M Johnny dodges a kick or two before he finally arrives at He UPENDS the sack over the pit and a dozen live RATS tum GAMEMASTER slips Johnny a couple of cents as he starts hi

Alright, gents and ladies, your bets now on Towser agains count to beat is ten rodents in three minutes. The crowd starts to place bets. A sleepy Johnny settles d ringside to watch the show. At a signal from the Gamemaster, a TRAINER tosses TOWSER- mongrel--into the ring. The crowd cheers lustily, continu bets, as the dog goes after the rats.The rats, fighting f bite the dog, attaching themselves to his body. Towser re gnawing the rats, SNAPPING them in half and spitting them As the CROWD cheers, and Towser kills, and money changes curls up and goes to sleep.
A row of cells, noisy and cold. The GUARD shoves Amsterda

You get to live private until they come from the orphan's account of your tender years. There is nothing in the cell but a board for a bed, and a which Amsterdam can see the late winter moonlight. He loo the sky, but can see none.
Jenny Everdeane and a girl FRIEND, her own age, huddle to corner of this huge space. The Friend opens her hand to s glimpse of what she's clutching: a penny.
Let me see! I don't believe it.
(closing her hand) No! It's a danger.
Oh come on! It's not. (Friend shakes her head) Then tell me where you got it.
From some man. He took me in his carriage. He only wanted to me fast.
What?
(shrugs) I didn't understand.
Would he do the same with me?
I won't tell you if he's around again. (clutches penny tight) He's my secret.

Better keep it more careful, then. The Friend GETS UP and starts across the Brewery floor, a But she looks around her, across the sleeping, passed-out desperate families and their squalling infants, to see if noticed. A man and two women cast a glance her way. She looks away keeps watching her... then FANS OUT and starts to FOLLOW The Friend looks over her shoulder again. SEES the Man. L direction, SEES: the woman. And then: the second woman. A The Friend starts to RUN. The Trio runs after her. And no attention. The Friend PLUNGES into one of the warren of T off the Brewery floor. CAMERA plunges through the darkness, after her. Her foots is the SOUND of stumbling, falling, an angry CURSE and a struck. The FRIEND picks herself up out of the darkness a CAMERA following down the dank halls. Suddenly the TRIO runs AHEAD of the camera. There is a SC staps. And others SOUNDS follow quickly now: the dull THU object against bone, REPEATED several times; and then, ve the most terrible sound of all: silence. Then Two Women emerge from the darkness of the tunnel, fi penny. The Man, several steps behind them, throws an obje floor: it's a STONE, and it is covered with blood. He com Two Women quickly and GRABS the penny from them with a ha DRIPS blood and gore. They CHASE after him across the cro floor.
CAMERA races along the ornate corridor, past PORTRAITS of and self-important GENTLEMEN... through a door and into..

... Tweed's domain. Small in size, but there are dozens o CANARIES all around. Tweed looks up startled as the door birds set up a COMMOTION. CAMERA bears down on Tweed as a pair of HANDS grabs him a against the wall. Bill The Butcher GLARES at Tweed. Some NATIVES come into him.
You come into the Five Points and you stole from me.
I don't know...
You stole Vallon. He was my kill. My example, of my power and made him yours.
You're a lunatic to come here like... In the background, same of the NATIVES have begun to play removing the CANARY CAGES from their places and tossing t room.

Thank you. Just listen good. The Native Americans holds t We have prevailed. What you do outside the Points is your Outside is your city. Inside the Points is mine. Anyone w different, or does different, or thinks different... (smiles) ... theylll draw my unwelcame attention. You understand?
I do understand, yes. BILL pushes him away and starts out.
But you don't understand at all. Bill keeps walking.
There's a whole city to share and all you see is your own
(turns now) You just stay out of my place.
Yes, alright. Gladly. It's all blackjack jobs and panel g for a fiver. Bill waits for Tweed to continue. But Tweed stoops and tr canary in a cage.
It's good work.
As far as it goes.
You wouldn't be talking to me otherwise.
But we're talking about different things, Bill. You descr I see the possibilities. Look to the future. There is so The Butcher starts to look interested.
Later. The Natives have cleared out; only Tweed and the B The cages have been restored to their proper places and t straightened. Bill stands beside the door, while Tweed re

There's things demanding to be done that no police force an obedient one. There's contributions from every dive an Loyalties to be secured and debts to be collected. BOSS TWEED (Cont'd) And now you and your Natives have emerged as the foremost Five Points, I'm prepared to extend you an opportunity. Y Tammany...
We work for no one.

... beside Tammany... in the performance of these civic o for a satisfactory... I'm prepared even to say equitable. participation. It's not the sort of responsibility the fo might have recognized. But then, the founding fathers nev city New York has become.
Maybe you Tammany boys should do your own lifting and car work. Might build you up.
We'd like to. I do miss it. But it's wiser for men in the give an appearance of probity.
Then get cops to do it.
Oh Jesus, no. The appearance of law must be upheld, espec being broken.
Appearance means nothing.
Perhaps not within the Points. But the smart man could go Bill looks at Tweed for a long moment. The he SHOVES hims wall, pulls away the chair on which Tweed has been restin sits down close to him.
If you can talk plain, maybe we can do business.

A small slum thoroughfare congested by a splendid FIRE-WA "Americus Co./Tammany Hall." Curious SPECTATORS and panic RESIDENTS crowd around to watch a ramshackle building goi As Johnny presses through the crowd to get a good look at in a white coat and fancy fire helmet, steps off the fire an ONLOOKER.
Anyone inside?
No, praise God, but all we own... TWEED places a bucket over the only fire plug in the vici on it.
Well?
Waiting on reinforcements. The SOUND of another bell, nearby. Down the street from t direction come TWO MORE FIRE-WAGONS. The crowd starts che not move from the plug.

That's not them. It's only the Black Jokes. Seems your fi their festivities. The wagons pull up next to the fire plug. Each of them ha "Black Joke Fire Co." written large on the side, but the party costumes, not regular uniforms. Some are dressed as Redcoats, still others as Indians. The FLAMES continue to devour the building, but Tweed doe the plug. He is approached by the Black Jake chief, who i Indian chief.
May I point out that the building is burning to ashes?

Certainly. And may I then remind you, Pocahontas, that th the province of the Americus company, and you will kindly distance. Impasse. The rival Fire Companies size each other up and other. The building continues to burn. Tweed remains rega atop the fire plug. As the two COMPANIES are about to close with each other, sounds. Tweed's "reinforcements" have arrived: the Native by Bill The Butcher. They PILE OFF the wagons before the the Black Joke Co. is outnumbered, and it FALLS BACK. As Tweed takes the bucket off the fire plug.

Alright, boys! To work! The MEN of the Americus Co. give a great SHOUT and start hose is hitched up to the plug, buckets are filled, a pri water spluttering everywhere. But there is not much blaze left to combat and the Men qu frustrated. Tweed realizes this immediately.

Next building over, boys! Mustn't let it spread! The men charge into a neighboring building, STOMPING down through windows and SWINGING AXES with gusto, all to save is in no danger at all. A local poll named DANIEL KILLORAN detaches himself from approaches Tweed, giving him a hearty SLAP on the back.
Another proud night for Tammany, Bill.

Just tell them... (lowers his voice) ... to take enough to share. And not to steal so in the o Indeed, the Men are leaving the building with lots of LOO question their right to do this are promptly KNOCKED DOWN Bill The Butcher as he rushes by.
Jesus! Boss says to tell you to fight the fire from the f the back. Bill grins and leaves to spread the word as an angry WOMA Tweed.
The Black Joke could have saved my house!
Black Joke had no business here, Madam.
Their business was to save my house!

Tammany's your business. When we're here to call upon the other. We understand loss, Madam, and take care of our ow As Tweed leads her off, away from the blaze and the thiev boy sitting an the curb, watching the fire ... and watchi admiration. It's Johnny. The FLAMES light up his EYES as we...
Jenny's face, as she tries to sleep on a narrow, filthy m mother Maggie lies beside her, crowding her, THRASHING ab troubled, drunken sleep.

Amsterdam, eyes wide, lying on a cot in the middle of a l with KIDS - This place is a step or two up from the Brewe step. He stares at the ceiling, eyes grave, untroubled by of loneliness and fear that come from some of the beds su we move CLOSE on his EYES we...

head_text.subj: EXT. HIGH BRIDGE ORPHANS ASYLUM DUSK

text: ... the same eyes. But OLDER. Smart and full of savagery. It is Amsterdam. He is now in his early 20s, fully grown trifle with. Moving with jungle stealth and strength he . ... BURSTS out the door within the massive frame of a gre which hangs the sign "High Bridge Orphan Asylum." He star TITLE comes up... 1852 Pursued by GUARDS, Amsterdam runs hell-for-lather for a l bridge. It's a beautiful, stern old Romanesque span acros River with rolling banks of leafy trees on the far side. twilight, we can see that it is late spring, the end of a
Amsterdam is on the bridge. But he does not slow up until ... two orphanage GUARDS suddenly TACKLE him. A THIRD GUA a billy club. Amsterdam moans and curses, as much from fr
It's Blackwell's Island certain now, boyo. The SECOND GUARD pulls AMSTERDAM up by the hair.
Are you hurting? Let's hear you! Amsterdam won't give him the satisfaction. The Guard hits goes down, biting his lip so he won't cry out. Instead, h
There's nothing funny, boyo! You been beat and turned bac
But every time you bring me back... you got to come furth

Through the THICK FOG comes a ghostly apparition: a tatte CROSSBONES, made of rags, fluttering from the mast of a l vessel. The bow of the small boat breaks the fog, and on board we called SHEENY MIKE KURTZ and a huge black kid named JIMMY the cars. Johnny Sirocco, grown wary and wiry, peers into lookout, while Shang Draper, at the tiller, looks anxious The HULL of a large boat suddenly laoms in front of them, away.
Hard starboard, Shang! Hard starboard!
(panic) I told you forget that sailor stuff! Which way's star... Too late. Their Ticket craft crashes into the side with e make a LOUD THUMP and to send Shang sprawling.

(sarcastic) Why don't we just knock on their front door? Shang gestures for QUIET. They wait and listen. No sound the boat above them. The boys throw two ROPE LADDERS over larger ship and start climbing.
The boys board the ship and gather on deck. They look aro spooked by the silence and the fog.
Spread out and make for the cabin. Moving slowly, the boys FAN OUT and move toward the cabin of the deck. Johnny stays close to Shang, holding onto th support.
(whispering) Nothing. Looks picked clean. Johnny stops. His hand, on the railing, is BLOODY. On the the deck, Sheeny Mike discovers more traces of blood and
Bill and the Natives must have got here first. Johnny freezes in terror.

What ... A long SHADOW falls across his shoulder. Shang jumps. Standing before him, holding a musket and covered in bloo CAPTAIN. A BUTCHER'S CLEAVER is imbedded between his neck With his dying energy, the Captain takes AIM at a petrifi fires his musket. Jimmy Spoils JUMPS the Captain from behind, sending the m wide. But the SOUND of the musket is thunderaus, and echo harbor. The boys panic and head for the side.
That'll bring the Harbor cops for sure.
(about the dead man) Wait! Take him. If he's still alive he's good for ransom!
Hels dead as Good Friday, can't you...
Then we'll take Bill the Butcher's cleaver and sell the b medical students. They'll go five dollars for it anyway.
Come on. We'll get something out of this. Shang and Johnny start DRAGGING the body. Pushing, pullin panicked, the others help. As they boost the body over th of a bell cuts through the fog.
The Harbors! Shang shoves the body off the side and into the boat. It resounding THUD. The boys CLAMBER after it.

PUSHING OFF with cars, tearing their rope ladders from th ship, stumbling over the captain's body, the boys slip of The Harbor Police are so close to them they can see a pol shining. The boys stay absolutely still. Suddenly, WE SEE BOAT, breaking through the fog, then DISAPPEARING again.
We can't go back to Corlears Hook, they'll be watching...
We'll make for Blackwells.

And which way's that through this fog? Johnny throws his hands up for quiet. From close by comes COP'S VOICES. They are near. Very near. The boys stay as can... ... and the VOICES recede again in the thick fog.
Should have asked them directions as they drifted by, Sha
You'd have liked that, wouldn't you Coal Face? You're the miss in the dark.
Let's quiet, or we'll all be found out! As the BOYS stay still, their boat DRIFTS against an outc and STOPS.
Alright. We lay up here till first light. Then we run bac river.
(contemptuously) River pirates! Spoils settles back and tries to sleep. Johnny watches Sh Shang is too agitated to notice Johnny's stare. He looks the sun.

Shang drowses in the boat, fighting fatigue, then succumb h's brought awake suddenly by a loud SPLASH. He looks in the noise, SEES ... ... the BODY of the slaughtered ship's captain floating a company. He starts to cry out but Amsterdam GRABS him, lo in the crook of his arm.
(to everyone) Push off! Or his pipe snaps! The other boys are too stunned to resist. They push the b island.
Head straight out, then turn for the current. He pushes Shang away from him. The two boys stare at each remembering...
(breathing hard) Figured you for dead.
Close enough.
This is my crew. And welcome to join, if you've the mettl pirates and quick thieves and street brawlers...
(casual disdain) You're lost.
Yeah? You've no business saying anything against us! Do y you cost us? You know how much that body's worth?
I doubt it's worth the water it's floating in.
Fifteen dollars! Fifteen dollars from them medical ghouis
I'll make it back for you whatever it is, once we're in t keep sailing, or we're all done for.
(beat; to crew) Go ahead then. (beat; to Amsterdam) He was in his prime. He'd have fetched thirty dollars eas
A ramshackle room near the docks. It is part meeting hall quarters for the gang, and part clearing house forstolen presides over a boisterous meeting.
You're as flat as Broadway going north. We can't run the We're poaching the Natives and the Harbor cops are lookin
The cops can go to blazes. Who cares about them?
Youlre all sand when it comes to cops, Shang. But do you go against the Natives?
It ain't the time to go against the Natives. We've got to Then we go.
If we go like we did in the river, all of us'll sink. Amsterdam is sitting off to the side, watching this ongoi contemptuous detachment. Johnny sits next to him.
Does Shang have the sand to ever go against the Natives?
I don't know. He acts like it.

If he only acts, held be better on the stage. (looks away) Like her. His tone of voice has changed. Jenny Everdeane passes bef ravishing. Amsterdam STARES, as if he's trying to see int Jenny pays him scant attention as she moves across the ro
Jenny Everdeane. Shang turned her into the best bludget i Jenny gives Shang silk scarfs, wallets and several purses
Shes his mort, is she, as well as his best provider?
Yeah. But Jenny says she's anyone's she chooses. Jenny's haul is impressive. Shang picks a BRIGHT RED SILK distinctive PAISLEY design from the pile of stolen goods. with a shrewd, appreciative eye.
That's the prize of the month. Spice Islands silk. He puts the scart in his coat pocket with a FLOURISH, the about Jenny in a proprietary way.
You'll learn our way if you're going to be one of us, Ams Jenny reacts slightly to the mention of the name: she loo RECOGNIZES Amsterdam now.
Every one of us gives a portion of all they steal to the than men, being morts.
Yeah? And why is that?
Because morts have more resources. Men can work only on t mort can turn out on her back.
I mean, why give at all? Why don't they keep for themselv
If you think there's something off about my way of runnin no place in this gang.
I got no place anyway, and you got no gang. This ain't a what you say. It's a mob. There's a tense hush in the grubby room. Shang takes his Jenny, wanting to be restrained.

(smiling) It's all your play now, Shang. Maybe you can set him righ Jenny hands him a cane. Barely managing to hide his reluc starts--slowly--toward Amsterdam, who stands his ground. back to give them room in this tiny space. Shang pulls th it's a SWORD CANE, but Amsterdam shows no fear. He shifts little, watching ... and they're interrupted by a...
You boys settle with me before you settle each other. They turn to him.

I've come for my due and proper, Shang. Happy Jack Mulraney (the Dead Rabbit gang member with the face) stands before them in a POLICEMAN'S UNIFORM-sparkli splendid--a leather helmet and long coat. In his hand, he NIGHTSTICK.
As agreed, then, Jack. Refreshment? Shang OPENS the top of the gold-handled sword cane. Insid solid LUMPS of cocaine. Jack reaches for the choicest.
Still smiling, are you?
(sizing him up) It's the young Vallon, is it? I hardly recognized you.

I hardly knew you under that hat, Jack. By now, Jack has taken not only the cocaine, and the mone offers, but several of the purses and wallets Jenny deliv stares at him with contempt, and he laughs, tossing one o at her.
There. For your respect. Jack turns to leave but a BRASH BOY blocks his way. Movin Jack bashes the Boy to the floor with his nightstick.

Anybody else? Any number at all, come on. Several of the gang make a move toward Jack, but Shang WA Jack departs UNHARMED, to general disgust. Jenny walks ba room to help the Brash Boy. Shang GLARES at Amsterdam, sl back into his cane and follows Jenny, trying to explain h
Is that sand we've just seen?
It's politics.
A hot summer day. All the TRADESMEN are out in force, jam and the side streets leading to it. Amsterdam walks fast crowd, enjoying the freedom and the bustle, as Johnny tag behind him.
I've got my own way to go, why don't you find yours?
Because your way's different, and I want to see where it (Amsterdam looks at him) Unless you say otherwise. Amsterdam shrugs and keep walki
You act like you have something in mind, like you know ev you'll be doing the next. Me, I don't figure on tomorrow.
Well, if you shut up a while maybe it'd come on its own. (he stops, looks) Now what the hell's that?

(following his glance) Oh that's heaven. WE SEE what they're looking at: the Old Brewery. In worse before, but shut-down, abandoned. A tattered banner flaps front door: "Future Home of the Five Points Mission/ Prai Reverend Shadrach Raleigh, Pastor."
The city shut down the Brewery as unfit to live and Tamma to this minister.
What's Tammany?
Why Tammany ... you don't know? Tammany makes the city ru organization that's like... like the Native Americans, on the whole city.

As Johnny continues to speak, we see Tammany tactics in a WARD-HEALERS dispensing coal to the poor, and TOUGHS stea butcher's wagons; a political PARADE with fife and drum-a politicians--including Boss Tweed--in ceremonial Indian c group of GOONS busting up a saloon; Tweed making a speech CONSTITUENTS and a Tammany Fire Company tearing through t scattering everyone in their way, finally revealing they to a fire but are CRASING OFF a rival fire company.
They seem like the law, but they got a way of acting outs Anything that happens in this city, on the straight or on Tammany's a part of, and Boss Tweedls the heart of Tamman
Amsterdam studies Johnnyls enthusiastic face.
They're the best gang there is.
So if Tammany's the best, go with Tammany. What are you r mob for?
'Cause they're more my size for now. With Tammany, you go large, something that makes them take notice of you.
You're better oft without their notice. You can run free, schemes.
But if your schemes have size, you need size to bring the
What are you thinking? Johnny shrugs, grins: he doesn't want to give anything aw understands, turns toward the Brewery.
Let me in if you ever get it figured. Amsterdam starts toward the Old Brewery, Johnny keeping s
I'll go on my own from here. Johnny STOPS and Amsterdam continues on by himself.
Echoing. Dank. Amsterdam holds a candle high for light. R crosses the main floor, enters one of the side tunnels.
A tiny room we recognize from the first scene: this is th Amsterdam lived with his father. He crouches and TEARS UP floorboards, then quickly LOWERS HIMSELF into the hole.

A short tunnel under the Brewery floor, the kind a kid mi Amsterdam has trouble crawling through it. DIRT and ROCK until he finds what he wants stuck in a shallow hole; a b MONEY PURSE; and a PAPER-WRAPPED PACKAGE. Amsterdam snaps open the purse to make sure the little bi still there, then turns his attention to the package. He Inside is the PIRATE KNIFE that Bill the Butcher used to father. Amsterdam handles the knife carefully as he opens it. The makes the blade GLEAMS.

A shock of summer SUNLIGHT as Amsterdam emerges from one entrances of the Brewery onto a fetid alley filled with r broken glass and insensible drunks. Amsterdam looks carefully up and down the alley, letting to the bright light. Ahead of him, he SEES ... Shang Draper, in jovial conversation with a SECOND MAN we recognize. The man is bareheaded, and has a deep scar run front clear down the center of his bald head. Amsterdam w Shang takes the RED SILK SCARF he got from Jenny's swag a the Second Man. He and Shang SHAKE HANDS, as if they have business deal, and the Second Man walks away. Amsterdam PRESSES himself close to the door as Shang LOOK doesn't see Amsterdam... and walks off in the opposite di Paradise Square.

head_text.subj: INT- RECEPTION ROOM AND TWEED'S OFFICE DAY

text: The main room is as loud and as prosperous as the stock e Butcher makes his way past Small GROUPS of men engaged in dealings of dubious virtue. Bill knocks on the door to Tweed's private office while h Inside is Boss Tweed, seated in a large WOODEN BOX like a Around him are various PETITIONERS, and his assistant Dan
I dread city stimmers. They bring illness and beget vermi PETITIONER #l (GLEASON) My plague box fends off all pestilence. Its elixir combat
We can't have every citizen of the Five Points boxed up l
But the season is vicious, and I must take thought of our Mr. Gleason, I'd like you to shake hands with Mr. Barnett Gleason, dubious, shakes hands with PETITIONER #2 as Bill looks on with amusement.
A friend and owner of an estimable carting service. Work arrangement whereby the citizenry can receive the benefit wondrous elixir outside this excellent box. At a cost, Mr much the barrel ...
(figuring rapidly) Oh, perhaps twenty-five dollars.
...and how much, Mr. Baff, for haulage and distribution..
The same again. At least.

At least. That's a price of fifty dollars. And greedy, lo (Gleason and Baff splutter) But a price that Tammany, in its generosity, will meet. M bill for a hundred. We'll each have half. And I'll retain further experiment. Hello, Bill. Killoran LEADS the astonished Gleason and Baff away as Bi
Bolt the door. Bill complies. As Tweed speaks and the anti-plague VAPORS head, he keeps his eyes closed.
Scotchy Lavelle's gone wrong in his accounts.
I know. Scotchy's a good man.
Not good enough to rake thirty percent of our share from it for his own. (opens his eyes) You got to give him over, Bill.
I can't do that. No matter what he steals, I still get mo any two others. As do you.

Alright then. What about Charles McGloin? He's running a one side. Did you know that? (Bill shrugs) I can't get a day's work done for all the good citizens p complaining about crime and corruption all over the Point Tammany of carelesoness. Some even suspect ... a few prac (eying Bill significantly)  ... our complicity with this rampant criminality. We must Tammany stands behind the letter of the law. We need to s
(beat) Charles McGloin will do.
I'll set the trial for Friday.

CAMERA moves high along the outside wall, past small rect that pass for jail windows. EYES peer out, as if a peep s directly below in the Tombs courtyard. A PRISONER is bein gallows by having a hood tied to his head. The CROWD is in a carnival mood; HOT CORN GIRLS, STREET V "HOKEY-POKEY" (i.e., ice cream) MERCHANTS, even BUSKERS, holiday spirit. Jenny works through the crowd, pushing and smiling her wa raucous merrymakers. She stops once or twice to have a wo GENTLEMAN, flirts for a moment, then moves on. Further back in the crowd, Amsterdam NOTICES her. He watc through the crowd with an admiration that quickly turns t he realizes what she's doing: picking pockets. The best b Five Points. He starts to FOLLOW her. Jenny has worked her way close to the hanging platform, b intent on her job she has not noticed Amsterdam. The clos the closer the spectacle and richer the pickings: Jenny's absolute. On the platform, an ASSISTANT HANGMAN addresses
Those interested in the effects of the condemned please c
Part of the Crowd PRESSES in toward the platform, tempora Amsterdam's view of Jenny. He is right against the platfo
What am I bid for this coat? A coat of some wear but exce containing a rather remarkable pocket silk...
Bid a quarter!

A quarter, thank you. Do I hear fifty cents? Fifty cents? The Hangman is holding up the condemned man's coat which SILK SCARF Amsterdam saw Shang give away. Amsterdam flips quarter, reaches out and GRABS the handkerchief.
Here. Just for the silk. He stuffs it into his pocket and starts to PUSH his way t On the platform, the WARDEN steps forward holding a primi
Do you have any last remarks, Charles McGloin? McGloin grunts from underneath the hood.

Not from under this hood I don't. Crowd near the platform begins to CHANT "No hood, no hood Warden puts his hand on the hood, starts to remove it... ... and the Crowd CHEERS. Amsterdam turns, SEES: Charles with a deep scar running front to back on his head. The v saw in the alley with Shang. McGloin acknowledges the cheers of the crowd. The Warden megaphone close and McGloin bellows...

I never struck a foul blow or turned a card and may God g friend! The Crowd ROAR approval at these words. Amsterdam PUSHES crowd, looking for Jenny ... SPOTTING her finally... ... while up on the platform, the NOOSE is placed around and he is HOISTED UP in no time. We hear his neck SNAP. H after death. The Crowd raises a zighty cheer.

head_text.subj: EXT./INT. BROADWAY AND BROADWAY STAGE DAY

text: Amsterdam walks with a crowd toward a waiting Broadway st that looks like a horsedrawn train car. The stage will ta back uptown from the hanging. He is working his way toward Jenny, who is now BOARDING t Amsterdam DASHES through the crowd and SQUEEZES onto the moves forward with a JOLT. Once on board, Amsterdam looks through the jammed car, SE to sit down - A MAN has offered her his seat. She smiles sits... ... and arranges her hands genteelly on her lap. The Man and she smiles up at him again. He is bequiled. Amsterdam manages to get a little closer.
I hope you won't think me rude if I speak.

No, sir. You look a proper Gentleman down to the ground. As this conversation continues, we watch-not only Jenny a conversation, and Amsterdam watching them; but we begin t Amsterdam SEES. Although Jenny's hands apparently remain lap, her RIGHT HAND moves SLOWLY out from her wrap... tow

Well, I wouldn't want you to think me forward, you see. ... and BRUSHES past his jacket. He does not notice or fe Jenny's hand GLIDES past his THIGH ... nearly brushing it across his pelvis and around his buttocks...
Does it matter to you what I think?
Well, I might like it to.

Oh. ...toward his pocket. The Man is in Jenny's thrall. He fe continues to have no idea what is going on. But Amsterdam silken, surreptitious move of her HAND across The Man's b CARESS that Amsterdam can feel. Jenny's grace is balletic she picks The Man's pocket, she is, without knowing it, a Amsterdam
I mean, if you would like.
I might like, sir. But I can't say now. Her hand HOVERS above his pocket, waiting for the SWAY of match and mask her movement....

Why? ... and she starts to get up as soon as the stage JOSTLES full of passengers LEANS into one another... ... and Jenny's hand SLIDES the Man's WALLET from his tro he recovers his balance. Amsterdam watches her withdraw h flash and hide it beneath her wrap.
Because this is my stop.
May I walk with you a little, then?
(firmly) That would be too bold.
But I'll never see you again.
I come every Thursday to the Tombs to see my father.
I'll look for you. Jenny fetches him another fine SMILE--it's almost demure- way off the rear entrance of the stage. lt PULLS AWAY up Broadway and Jenny walks briskly toward

Jenny looks to make sure she has the alley to herself, th a little... ... and her arms seem to come off. She has been wearing a ARTIFICIAL ARMS, hollow inside, which she can leave folde misleadingly while she goes about her pickpocketing. She's folding up the appliance--cotton sewn over a soft f behind her makes her turn.
May I walk with you a little, then?
As Jenny and Amsterdam walk through the noisy bustle of t thoroughfare.
Are you a spy, then?
Got no one to spy for. I'm an appreciator, you might say.
Appreciator of what?
A good touch. She STOPS in the street, looks him straight in the eye.
Don't bother with the chat. If you want me, we come to a arrangement. lf the terms is right, then I decide how you do it or not.
Just take a minute, I was Just...

I know what you was just. I had years already of what you know how I got so good at thieving? So's I wouldn't have everyone who had the ned. Now I do it when I want to for to. Otherwise I don't do it, and don't have to do it, and anyone's rules but my own.
What about Shang's rules? You pay a lot over to him. The the better his. It don't seem gute right.
(a little curious now) What's it to you?
Give him this. He hands her the RED SILK SCARF. She recognizes it instan one she gave Shang.
And you can keep a little more of what you earned.
How'd you come by this?
I got my own touch.
Are you making me a present, or making an Arrangement?
It's your rules, right? So you decide. She looks at him for a moment, then starts to TIE the sca neck like a kerchief.

A gentlemen's WALLET skims across a pitted wooden table, Shang's hand. Jenny is giving him her CUT. He opens the w at Jenny. No more goods are forthcoming. Amsterdam, hangi them both. Shang SEES the RED SILK SCARF, tied around her neck.
Pretty slim cut for a hanging day. Where'd you get that?
From Amsterdam.
(beat) It don't suit you.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET AND PARADISE SQUARE NIGHT

text: A SWELTERING evening. The streets are jammed with REVELER Some people sleep in doorways in futile search for fresh Mulraney leads a group of apprehensive UPTOWN CITIZENS pa whores.
Commissioner Brunt said to spare you nothing concerning c
Nothing but our safety, of course.

All's snug around Paradise Square in my company, squire. He gestures toward the street, down which one oi Mr. Barn is being drawn by a team of WHEEZING NAGS. The cart bears massive barrels of what a colorful banner anti-pestilence influenza-thwarting solution... a service Hall." As the wagon draws abreast of a large group of lan RESIDENTS, HOSES spurt waves of solution all over the str are SOAKED. Jack and his Citizens jump back just in time.
Tammany makes the streets nanitary, I make 'am safe.
(apprehensive) Even against them? A small distance behind the anti-plague cart, moving in r come some of Shang's mob, heading aimlessly across the Sq action
Against them especially. Let me demonstrate. Jack takes out his GOLD WATCH AND CHAIN, which he HANGS c nearby lamppost. Then, very casually, he leads the Citize
We'll be back for this at our leisure.
You dare leave it here?

Safe as a vault, lady. Since all knows it's mine. The Gang draws abreast of the lamppost. No one makes a mo watch until one of the YOUNGEST BOYS reaches out ... but Shang knocks his hand away. Jack, at a distance, NODS app
You know that's Jack's.
So what?
It should be hangin' off Jack's vest, then. Not here, lik
That watch is a small price for free run of the Points.
If it's free, how come we pay so much? Wo shouldn't pay f
We don't tight when we don't have to. It's not warring th the living day to day.
(smiles) Is that right? Did I hear that correct? John, did we hear Eyes now on Johnny. Jenny looks at him with great interes
(uneasy pause) We heard the same.
So then. He reaches for the watch.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET AND PARADISE SQUARE NIGHT

text: Happy Jack stands at the lamppost, aghast. A WOMAN lowers retches. Jackls watch and chain are still in place. But the watch has been SMASHED. And hanging from the chai skinned and strangled.
Happy Jack stands with his Citizens. The room QUIETS as, mob notices him.
You! He GRABS the Young Boy who had reached for his watch on t starts to BEAT him.
What'd you do to my watch, you dirty little bastard... Jack breaks the Boy's hand with his nightstick. The Boy S and FAINTS. So does one of the Women in the group. Jack t other hand.
Hands won't be so quick in future.
That's enough sport this evening, Jack.
(stepping forward) It wasn't him. All turn to look at Johnny. Jack drops the Boy's hand.
I have word for you from who did it. You're to meet him a Chinese Pagoda.

A low and lunatic place: a combination of an opium dream Arabian Nights and a panel from a Bosch triptych. FAN-TAN Orientals; WOMEN and CHILDREN of various colors suspended the ceiling as MEN and WOMEN in a secondfloor GALLERY poi JOKE. On the main floor, a long line waits for a shot at All-Sorts. Jack charges in the front door, looks around.

All right, step out, you yellow... All the NOISE subsides. Only the Fan-Tan game continues; nothing is so interesting that these Orientals will stop Now Amsterdam STEPS right in front of him. It's a grandst
Hello, Happy Jack. I'm the one you're looking for.

Then you're marked for dead. Jack lunges ahead, swinging his NIGHT STICK. Amsterdam th across his path. Jack stumbles, goes down, dropping his n Amsterdam grabs it, jumps on top of him, HITS him twice o head. There is a CRACKING SOUND. The PATRONS of the Pagod

Later. Festive again. And no sign of Amsterdam. Two PATRONS step away from the all-sorts barrel. Hanging like the cat from the watch chain is the BODY of Happy Ja belt has been removed from his trousers, tied like a NOOS throat, then looped over the spigot. His TEETH lie scatte around him. His NIGHT STICK has been jammed down his thro
Amsterdam holds the FANCY COAT from Jack's uniform over h Carefully, he DRAPES the coat over Jenny's shoulders. SHA
I gave no order for this. Amsterdam says nothing at first, just holds his hand out: RED SILK SCKRF.
(very quietly)  Never mind giving orders. What were you giving this for?
I'm calling you out, Amsterdam.
I got this at the hanging. It was Charles McGloin's. Ever you take it from Jenny. What was MCGloin doing with it? W to him for?
I didn't give it to him. Why would I give it to him?
I gaw you give it to him. Last week, behind the Old Brewe
(to group) He's gone flat. I got no reason to trade with the Native
What about stepping up in the world, as it were, and leav us behind. There's a reason. Making a separate arrangemen with the one Native so stupid and luckless that he got hu the ground, Shang.
(very edgy now; to group) Who believes what he's saying? Can any of you believe wha

Bene. We'll see. Any of you that believes I did proper by Mulraney tonight, stand beside me. Any of you that still with the cops, and Shang's way with the Natives, go to hi (to Shang) Or should we settle right now, you and me, and just see w left standing?
Let see where they stand. Jenny rises, stands next to Amsterdam. Jimmy Spoils, John are next. Now the other members of the mob move in cluste with Amsterdam.

What's your pleasure, Shang? One of the YOUNG BOYS has a dead rat blackjack hanging fr Shang grabs it. He BITES the head oft the rat and spits i Amsterdam. Amsterdam almost smiles at him. Shang sneers, the rat, and LEAVES.
This mob ever have a proper name?
We was called after Shang when we was named at all.
We're the Dead Rabbits from now. They were the best. They They were legend, and we'll live up to them.

Amsterdam sits on an empty pier, watching the ships in th a SUDDEN RUSTLING NOISE as a NOOSE coils around his neck. It's Jenny. She's slipped the SILK Amsterdam gave her clo and she's TIGHTENING it. Amsterdam starts to resist. Then she's looking at him. She uses the silk to bring his face closer to hers. She K
What's this then?
Payment for the silk. Then DROPS the silk from his throat and starts to touch h hands are under her skirt. Then, under the cloudy moonlig make love.
Later. Amsterdam pulls Happy Jack's uniform COAT over Jen warm in the chill air.
You were waiting for me out here, weren't you?
Maybe I was, yeah.
You was that sure of me?
Sure enough to wait, anyway. Waiting don't cost nothing.
It don't do to be sure. I could go away just as easy.
Alright. He sweeps the coat away from her body, allowing her to le
I'll say when I want to, not you.
Stay then. (beat; smile) One way or another, I get what I want.
(looking at him) Yeah. If it was just a shag you wanted.
You're a gypsy, are you, come to tell my fortune? Go ahea what I'm wanting.
You got blood in your eye for someone.
It's just I can't look away, that's all.
Who from?
Bill Poole.
You better get someone else in your sights. No one's ever
'Cause he's mine, that's why. I'll take his one eye, and him, piece by small piece.
You have a plan for this? You going to raise a militia? I the Butcher don't even know about you or care if he does.
He'll know about me soon enough.
And after the Butcher?
You.
Is that so?
You'll be in love with me.
Love you? You just had me. You can have a mort any time y look for more than that.
That's taking love, not giving it. I want it to be just y else for either.
Why?
'Cause none of us means nothing in life except one to the
I don't know I want to mean something, to you or anybody. good in that? He stares at her.
We'll see. Jenny pulls the coat tighter around her.
It'll take a while if we do. If we ever do.
And what about the meantime?
Meantime's business.

A CROWD gathers in one of the main thoroughfares bisectin beefy SPEAKER is making an anti-Irish speech on behalf of a mayoral candidate supported by Tammany's current rivals Know-Nothing Party. Hand-painted signs are everywhere, be unsavory likeness. A couple of BUSKERS provide a musical political spiel.

The potato is a thick vegetable. Heavy. Meaty. Comes out dirty and stays that way unless you scrub it and boil it (cheers and laughs from crowd) We don't want to keep lem out of the country! We'll even at our table! But we ain't gonna vote 'em into office. Much CHEERING and jovial approval from the Crowd. On its Amsterdam and the Dead Rabbits make their way roughly acr
Any Irish hears that will be out for blood.
The Irish is too busy building up Tammany. That's where t muscle goes. Once they're inside with their cronies, they own outside. Tammany'd steal the air and rent the dayligh
We'd do the same. AMSTERDkM Not against our own we wouldn't. That's the difference.
Tammany earns better. That's the difference.
I ain't seen their ned yet. Johnny stops walking, betraying slight annoyance that he the day's deal.
You will at day's end, that's our arrangement. A quarter they're repeaters or not. I'm telling you, we got a squar
It's sound, Amsterdam.
Yeah? Well, it's ned anyway. Just make sure you count it
It's just a day's job, we don't have to make it a life's Tammany today and kill them tomorrow, if that's our pleas
So we're politicians just for today.
Not for a minute. We're better than that. We're thieves.

The Dead Rabbits go about the business of rounding up Tam pick up DRUNKS in alleys; Jenny and some of the Dead Rabb PATRONS in a whore house; Rabbits shanghai SAILORS from s CITIZENS as they walk along the street, either wheedling get them to vote. It's the strong arm of democracy.

On one side of the door, some Dead Rabbits, with a RABBLE voters; on the other, POLICE doing their best. Behind and various WARD HEELERS and SMALL-TIME POLITICIANS, represen Know-Nothing candidate Barker and Tammany's Fernando Wood factions push and pull at one another as they wedge their polls.
He's got the right to vote, damn you!
Not four times he don't. (shoves a Voter) There'll be no damned repeaters here! The Cop and Jimmy play tug-of-war with a besotted VOTER, members rush to GRAB VOTERS leaving the polls. PANDEMONIUM.
The main floor is jammed with CLUBMEN and PARTY RACKS. Da bustles from group to group, making promises, taking note out Boss Tweed, who is holding court in a far corner, sur JOURNALISTS.

I would never speak ill of a rival. I would never say tha Know-Nothing is a horse thief. It is my observation, howe horse thief is a Know-Nothing. Good-natured LAUGHING all around. Even TWEED seems amused catches the Boss' eye and whispers to him.
The Know-Nothings are already finished, and there's four polls yet.
Keep our men voting. Everybody works today. It's not a vi Daniel. I want a triumph.

head_text.subj: INT. DON WHISKERANDOSO BARBER SHOP DAY

text: Amsterdam roughly deposits REPEAT VOTERS in the barber ch BARBERS work FRANTICALLY to cut their hair, prune beards, alter appearances. As soon as one customer is done, Sheen with bay rum and pushes another REPEATER down in his plac count of the turnover.
Now that's eight... and how many still to come ... He looks toward the door, where more Repeaters are lined turn under close supervision.
I already voted once today. Cast for Tammany, by God, and
Once? Come here and do your duty. Amsterdam GRABS him and SLAMS him down in a chair.
Amsterdam and some RABBITS BURST into the front door, fri scattering all the Chinese GAMBLERS.
(barking orders) Line up like soldiers!
They got no notion what you're talking about.
(To Johnny) You explain their democratic right. Illl see they unterst Amsterdam GRABS the nearest two CHINESE by their PIGTAILS HURLS them against the wall.

Amsterdam and the Rabbits PROWL the murky darkness where in bunks stacked high against the walls. The Rabbits star rounding up the Opium Eaters. Jimmy Spoils SLINGS a coupl shoulder like flour sacks. Amsterdam SHOVES two more out admiring Daniel Killoran.
(to Johnny) I come to see if our counts square. You boys have made a showing....
Who the hell's this?
He's our Tammany man. Killoran compares his figures to the piece of paper where keeping his own count.
... remarkable...
(With an edge) Our own Tammany man. We are coming along. Happy to meet a Johnny Siroccols.
Likewise. Pleasure to meet the best but one in the whole
Best but one? Who's better? Killoran looks up. Johnny, standing behind Amsterdam, SHA VIGOROUSLY. Killoran gets the message.
(smooth) Maybe nobody. But when the count's done the numbers will out in front.
I'm in no race. Just pay us what you owe.
Tonight. At the victory celebration.

A Tammany victory celebration. When we last saw this plac confronted Happy Jack--the place was busy, alive. It's RI to bursting with POLITICIANS, CRIMINALS, GANG MEMBERS, MO HANGERS-ON, UPTOWN THRILL-SEEKERS, JOURNALISTS and COPS, off duty. The SOUND of the place is a cacophony of SHOUTI GAMBLING and STRANGE MUSIC--which we can't identify at fi CLOSE on a huge ruby ring and we HEAR...
Read what it says there, alongside the ruby...read it out ... and WE MOVE OUT as a WELL-WISHER reads the Latin insc
"Fortuna Juvat Ordentes."
A grand victory gift from the men of Tammany. Now, tell ' Mayor Wood.
"Fortune favors the bold." TWEED gives him a resounding slap on the back.
What do you think? Would that make a fit motto for our fa
Well, I could certainly see ...
(interrupting) We've got a motto.

what is it? (no one knows) Well, hell, let's get one we can remember. We're going to hall, we better have something to put over the front door you'll make sure the Latin's right? As Wood nods his assent, CAMERA MOVES across room... ... past the gilded CAGES suspended ten feet over the flo women and children look down at the action just below the of trepidation and resignation. Occasionally a REVELER wi and GRAB one of the caged inhabitants. Still MOVING, CAME ... passes a stage, where we finally SEE the source of al MUSIC we've been hearing: the music is provided by CHINESE MUSICIANS, a woman SINGER, a DANCER and some ACRO perform some weird, mangled Five Points version of Chines music and performance continues as we MOVE PAST... ... across a PEWTER FAN-TAN TABLE, where CHINESE GAMBLERS animation and concentration. By comparison, the Occidenta beside them seem like tourists. Everyone SHOUTS and SCRAMBLES to place bets with the FAN- Above the Dealer is an oval opening in the ceiling, throu PLAYERS may watch the action below. These FAN-TAN PLAYERS elegantly carved rail, peering at the action on the table their bets and collecting their winnings by means of a BA WIRES that whirrs constantly overhead. We continue to MOV ... until we are at the door of the place, where Amsterda Rabbits are having words with a BOUNCER.
I don't know you, you don't enter.
(enjoying himself) Come on, what are you saying? If you don't know us now, y tomorrow and you'll be working for us next week.
(more temperate) Daniel Killoran knows us.
Oh he does?
We work for him.
The hell we do.
(to Amsterdam) Tampen down, will you?
Why don't you all get the hell out of here and go fix on He SHOVES Johnny, who STUMBLES back into Amsterdam. They' and they step forward together toward the Bouncer... ... until Killoran intervenes.
(to Bouncer) It's all right, Nat. They're saying the truth. They gave for a good wage. Killoran HANDS OVER a paper-wrapped parcel of money, whic firmly.
A fine first showing. But second best.
Second, eh? You don't say so.
It's no shame to be bested by veterans. The Native Americ the field.
What?
We count on them sure as mass comes an Sunday.
(to Johnny, glaring) Did you know this? Is this some scheme of yours?
No, I didn't have no idea ...
I was working the same side as the Natives? The Natives?
That's only right. Bill the Butcher's our ambassador thro Points, as you might say. It's deemed an honor to work wi knows Bill Poole, everyone fears him, everyone ...
I sure as hell don't fear him. And I sure as hell won't s any who calls him one of theirs.
Well, if it's matter of personal honor, the money can onl insult. I have no wish to rile you further, so if you'll He REACHES to take back the parcel of money, but Amsterda away.
Where is he? Where's Bill the Butcher?

Listen, buck. This is a Tammany night. If you and Bill Po to settle, you can do it any other time, any other place, good dancing goddamn. But you do it here tonight and all will be down on you like the righteous wrath of heaven. o the Book says, put away childish things. Join the celebra I always find the least strenuous solution the most appea Amsterdam stares at him as we...

As a CHINESE ACROBAT TWIRLS in the air, off the stage, an middle of the audience. The crowd is raucously appreciati does GYMNASTIC MOVES among them... ... past a table where the Dead Rabbits have settled. it evening, and everyone has been drinking. Amsterdam, sullen, intense, WATCHES ... ..Bill the Butcher, across the room. He is like a prince pays him court, including several uniformed COPS, TAMMANY NEWSPAPERMEN. Bill receives the attention as his due.... ... while Amsterdam keeps watching, contempt and hatred g eye. He pays attention to none of the gang around, includ takes advantage of the situation.
I got experience. It's the education I lack.
And you heard I was a good teacher?
I don't listen to talk, I figure for myself. And I figure at everything you did.
That's right.
And tonight I got the ned.
And now what?
Now I'm ready for you. Unless there's an arrangement betw Amsterdam.
(glancing over at Amsterdam) Not to my thinking.
(needs to be sure) Amsterdam... listen up, Amsterdam... Amsterdam glances over at them.
(to Johnny) You going with me or him? It's my thinking matters here. ask him nothing.
What?
(makes his decision) How's the evening passing?
Fine. Why?
(puts his arm around Jenny) 'Cause it's treating me fine too. She gets up and starts toward the stairs to the second fl following her, holding her hand. As they pass Amsterdam h Jenny.
This is no game, you and me. Don't go on like it's a game

I said already, it's not a game. It's business. Johnny pulls her away. As he watches her go through the c gaze falls on Bill the Butcher again... ... and for the first tine their EYES MEET. Bill's eyes r take him all in... but DON'T REMEMBER him. He looks away steps up to pay court.... .... and a MASTER OF REVELS, center-floor, SHOUTS ...

Gentlemen and gentlewomen, if you please ... we will now. cages and start the bidding! The Crowd CHEERS and KIDS PULL on a series of ropes and p the CAGES further above the floor until they are parallel second-floor gallery of the Pagoda. WOMEN AND MEN call ou the cages rise through the air. Depending on their age, t children inside the cages respond to the auction with gri trepidation or fear. A few, drugged or drunk on all-sorts in their impossibly cramped space. Johnny and Jenny make their way along the second floor ga spots a COUPLE LEAVING a room and walks inside. Johnny CL behind them as a BURST of APPLAUSE... ... rises from the main floor, where Bill the Butcher sta center of the room.
