He slowly removes his coat and hands He is wearing his battle vest underneath, and it is fully his butcher's implements. The place QUIETS. KIDS swarm silently, like busy ants, al wooden CHANDELIER, LIGHTING its HUNDREDS of CANDLES. Only the Chinese playing fan-tan in the far corner of the room The Kids finish lighting the candles and the chandelier i the Pagoda ceiling, casting the whole place into a new ri SHADOW as The Butcher prepares himself. Now the Chinese Opera DANCER steps forward and stands nea The unsprung MUSIC begins. The DANCER starts to move, sin ...and Bill, with amazing skill, starts THROWING his KNIV MISSES the Dancer by a hairsbreadth, landing in the floor She doesn't flinch. She keeps dancing. And Bill keeps THR ... the KNIVES, which follow the Dancer around the room i deadly choreography. They land just inches from where she or will be: in a wall; a pillar; the apron of the small s the barrel of all-sorts. After each knife LANDS, kids ret one of the KNIFE KIDS pulls the blade from the all-sorts knock each other over to drink from the stream that flows Native Americans, meanwhile, WORK THROUGH the awed, atten AVOID Cops, Tammany Members and anyone who looks too pros sober. But when one of the Natives SPOTS a MARGINAL CITIZ hand and examine it as if they were telling fortunes. Center floor, Bill pulls TWO KNIVES out, BALANCES one in ... as a WHORE in the crowd pushes a guy who's groping he of Natives. Hels wearing a large RING. As soon as the Nat they throw their arms around the GROPER like a long-lost him to Bill ... ... who THROWS both knives rapidly at the Dancer. They la inches from her dancing feet. She SPINS AWAY to great app Natives bring the Groper to Bill.
Evening, sir. Are you prepared to be celebrated? Are you famous?
How much will it cost?
Just a moment of your time. My men will assist you. They do quite a bit more than that: they GRAB the Groper the floor. In the crowd, one SPECTATOR turns to his compa

Watch this careful. I've never seen the like, not even in The Groper CRIES OUT as the Natives PIN HIM to the floor, Bill has one weapon left... in a special pocket, inside h CLEAVER. He takes it out slowly, SAVORING the moment. The Pagoda goes QUIET. Only the gambling continues. The M only SOUND beside the noises of the Chinese at their fan- Groper, who HOLLERS for help as soon as he sees the cleav Bill HEFTS the cleaver in his hand, feels its weight, cal figures distance .... and starts THROWING it in the air.. ... CATCHING it by the handle ... then throwing it again. and HARDER with every toss.

(in full control) What's it so quiet for? I don't need quiet. The Chinese opera MUSIC commences with a dissonant CRASH. ... and Bill catches the cleaver again. But EVERY TIME he every time he catches it by its handle ... ... he also MOVES CLOSER to the terrified Groper. Now... very close... he gives the cleaver a mighty toss ... ... sending it SPINNING high in the air... up past the ca second-floor gallery, jammed with appreciative spectators SLOWS ... seems to HANG in the air... then starts its des ... FALLING FASTER... towards Bill's waiting, STEADY HAND The Groper SCREAMS in fear. Bill SMILES confidently, hold until ... just as smoothly, just as confidently... ... he PULLS his hand AWAY and the cleaver FALLS with ter the SPLAYED HAND of the Groper, cleanly SEVERING it at th Groper FAINTS dead away as a TREMENDOUS CHEER greets Bill One of the Natives TOSSES Bill the severed hand. Bill SLIDES the ring off the finger and TOSSES it to the

There's for your beauty and your song. The Dancer puts the ring on her finger and DANCES OFF. Bi hand to the floor and walks back to his table. The Crowd compliments on his dexterity, and the Knife Kids reverent Butcher's implements. Now two DOGS from the rat pit in the back room RUN throug FIGHT FRENZIEDLY over possession of the bloody hand. The Crowd PASSES the Groper overhead and WE SEE from ABOV unconscicus BODY being passed from hand to hand. The Crow wave bearing the body toward the door. The Groper's stump as he passes overhead, sprinkling drops of blood and fles sacrament. Bill approaches his table, acknowledging the continuing a about to sit down when a VOICE rises above all others.
Mr. Poole! Bill turns, searching out the voice ...
Bill Poole! And SEES Amsterdam, standing at his own table. His attitu smiling, respectful. But his eyes are demonic.
My compliments on your exhibition, sir.
Thank you, sir.
It was like watching a dance. (Bill nods his thanks) Some great grand goddamned dance. (Bill looks at him more You know me, sir.
Do I? Are you missing a finger? Appreciative laughter from the crowd.
No. A father. The laughter turns a little uneasy. Bill the Butcher size man.
Do you have a name?
Amsterdam.
That's a New York name. (suddenly smiles) shall we drink to it?
Indeed. (they drink) And to my other name. Vallon. Will you drink to that?
Priest Vallon's son? (Amsterdam nods) Of course I'll drink to that. Your father was a worthy ma

Not worthy of you. Those dogs ain't worthy of you. You ai they feed on, and what they shit's too good for you. DEAD QUIET. Absolute. Breathless. Only the Chinese Gamble fan-tan ignore this confrontation.
What do you want, boyo?
I got to give you something, Butcher. Something from my f Amsterdam PULLS OUT the piratels knife which Bill the But his father almost 12 years before.

You got the sand to draw a blade in front of me? You will Come ahead and give it here, you son of a bitch. And Amsterdam THROWS the knife, the bright blade FLASHING like lightning. And just as quickly the Buitcher PICKS UP his table, send flying and breaking, using it as a SHIELD... ... and the knife THUMPS into it dead center. The Butcher at Amsterdam...sending PATRONS yelling and SCATTERING. Amsterdam LEAPS out of the way of the table, then RUNS AT Butcher... ... who's already coming for him. As they CLASH and GRAPP other... ... PATRONS all over the Pagoda crowd around for a good v and start to MAKE BETS on the outcome. The odds do not fa And neither does the fight. Amsterdam fights with real bl doesn't have the Butcher's skill, or experience, or dispa the Butcher's CLINCH... HITS him once in the face... then ... and then gets FLOORED by a well placed kick. The Crow And, on the second floor, Jenny and Johnny come out of th arranging her clothes, Jenny looks over the gallery rail below, sees the fight... and starts to RUN down the stair her go ... looks at the fight again, for a second... then the main floor. The Butcher is on top of Amsterdam now. He HITS him upsid the wood and brass handle of his cleaver. Then hits him a In the Crowd now, Jenny finds Sheeny Mike.
The Butcher'll kill him if we don't do something.
It was Amsterdam's own doing. And it'll be our death too it.
(finally catching up) That's the truth.
The truth is you don't give a damn about him.

Yeah, well, if he gave a damn about us he wouldn't have c Butcher in the first place. Jenny looks at him with contempt, then STARTS into the cr her ARM but she pushes him off. On the floor, Bill uses the FLAT SIDE of the cleaver to S conscious Amsterdam on one side of his face... then on th REPEATEDLY... until Amsterdam is barely sensible. Bill gr hair. Amsterdam's body is slack.
What do you say? Loin or shank? Rib or chop? The Crowd YELLS their choices. Jenny tries to PLUNGE thro Amsterdam, but a HALF-DOZEN MORTS and WHORES put hands on back.

Come on, let me hear you! (the Crowd yells louder) You're all talking at once, I can't hear you! (a near frenzy) I don't hear the choicest cut! The best, the vital! (they quiet a little to listen) The heart. I think I must have the heart! This is greeted with the biggest CHEER of the night. The Mayor Wood seems to feel as if he should do something to slaughter, but Boss Tweed calms him with a single dismiss the Boss himself is excited by the prospect of this ritua

Come on, look at it! You fancy yourself a gladiator, act (raises his cleaver) Watch the death blow when it comes to you. Go to hell wit Bill the Butcher readies himself to deliver the blow... a his wrist, STOPPING his arm. Who would dare do this to Bill the Butcher? Bill turns, i look into... ... the untroubled face of Monk Eastman.
It's been a full evening's fun now, Butcher. It's enough.
You got nothing to do with this, Monk.
Well I'm the game warden, you might say. I'm telling you young yet. Wait till he's aged for a proper kill.
The hell. With his gigantic strength, Monk actually PULLS the Butch and onto his feet.
Just settle yourself Bill ... ... and he part SHOVES, part THROWS Bill back a good twen
... and let the merrymaking continue. The Dead Rabbits have scampered forward, and they're pick off the floor. Monk looks at Jenny and Johnny, who each h an arm.
It was his father took me in first, and it's thanks I'm r
Eastman!
(ignoring Bill) This squares any debt. Get him out of here.
Monk Eastman! As the Rabbits CARRY Amsterdam toward the door, Monk fina attention back to Bill.
I'll have you then!
Come ahead, Bill. Unless you're wanting to shout me to de And Bill comes forward, BRANDISHING his cleaver. Monk Eas ground, unmoving, untroubled. Everyone looks on in awe at ... except Boss Tweed.

(to Killoran) If these two are going to combat, it aught to be a worthi more rewarding for all. Tweed SIGNALS to Bill: STOP. The Butcher sees the signal it. He SHAKES his head. His blood is up. He won't stop. Tweed SIGNALS AGAIN. Bill KEEPS COMING. Tweed signals Killoran, who STANDS himself. And, when he and TAMMANY LOYALIST in the place--a hundred of them anyw Boss Tweed. As Bill keeps coming, and Monk stands easy, waiting... ... the Natives and their ALLIES now stand, facing the Ta Tammany backers, dressed flush and fancy, face the scruff Five Points bunch: the twin factions of the criminal unde different in style and so similar in purpose, SIZE EACH O opposite sides of the room. Bill STOPS. The odds are shifting, the stakes are climbin Chinese STOP GAMBLING. For the first time all evening the absolutely STILL. Even the Dead Rabbits have turned, at t what will happen. I only wanted to thank you, Bill, for the customary good an equally bright future for us both. Another pause. Bill does not look placated. The whole pla explode... ... until Boss Tweed RISES to his feet, and RAISES his gl

Will you drink with me, Bill, as a friend? An honored fri Bill weighs the proposition... then looks to his men, NOD call them off. He GRABS a glass off a table to join Tweed The MUSIC begins again. The gambling recommences. Patrons seats. The Dead Rabbits help Amsterdam out the door. Monk Eastman sidles up to Bill the Butcher.

If there's one thing I can't abide, it's fighting for fre He takes the Butcher's glass from his hand, raises it in DEEP and hands it back to him. He knew what he was doing, hitting you.
Let's get him up. She grabs Amsterdam's arm and, with Johnny's help, tries to his feet.

(Looking at Amsterdam's bloody face) Therels too damn little of him left to know anything. That so? What's he look like?
He looks pretty damned sorry.
(looks at Amsterdam) Indeed.- Can I buy you a shave?
No thanks.
Face is too sore, eh? I understand.
No. I'm beholden enough to you as it is. I don't like to
We're all even, son. There's nothing more between us.
I'd like it if there was.
Are you proposing employment?
A collaboration. The Dead Rabbits got to get strong befor move. I figure you're the one to make us strong. There's learn from you.
Boyo, I'm a freebooter and a mercenary, not a teacher. I nothing from you and I can't earn nothing from you either
The Dead Rabbits is going to be glorious again. We're goi the Points.
And Bill Poole's Natives? What will they have to say?
Nothing. They won't have tongues left to speak.

Don't worry about what theylll have in their mouths. You they got in their hands. (beat) Listen, son... take a word from a man who was honored to father. Temper yourself like a sword, and pay attention t spoils an edge.
Then you say no? Monk SIGHS and points to a huge WAR CLUB which hangs in a above the shop mirror. It has deep marks running along it

You see my instrument there? First notch represents two d cents. That's how much I got for my first kill. There are notches after it, and my fee has grown with each one. I c you alright, but you got to afford me. So do business wit your own.
Everything I got is still to come. So I guess it's on my
Fair enough. You'll find independence a fine thing, a fie Although I do hold money preferable to all. (Amsterdam turns to leave) But I'm sure we'll have news of each other.
Bound to. As he shuts the door of the shop, Monk Eastman gestures t Whiskerandos for another hot towel.

text: A large wagon bearing a Tammany banner and carrying dozen of coal moves slowly down the narrow street. Boss Tweed s seat, next to the driver, as his minions HAND him coal sa distributes them with a smile to the NEEDY who trot next

(to the people as they grab the coal) Tammany's here to take the chill off the winter and the w heart. It's Tammany can make this city a fit place, with of all you good people... As he continues, Bill the Butcher JUMPS onto the wagon an beside him. Boss Tweed hardly gives him a glance.
You sent me word.
We could use help here. Grab a sack.
I keep my hands clean.
(now he looks at him) So I've observed.
(tense) Better be on your mark to talk like that to me. It was yo the Pagoda. I would have cut Monk inside out.
What if you hadn't? Think of the embarrassment. And what Consider the waste. Next time you're in a dust-up like th and make proper plans. It'd be a grand source of revenue,
It touches my heart how you always. have our best interes
Our mutual interests. That's why I want you to contact Mo (Bill's incredulous) I want you to extend a proposition. I want him to join US
What?
Oh, not Tammany, of course not. We could no more have him But he should throw in with the Native Americans, become Arrangement and ... well, use his influence, shall we say all.
You're saying I can't do everything you need? You don't t has been doing good and right? You think there's somethin that I ...
(interrupting) It's none of that, Bill. None of that. His independence i to Tammany. And an insult to you.
Then you should have let me have him at Sparrow's.
I should. If I'd been confident-absolutely certain--that prevailed. Monk is an unpredictable power, and a figure o to be reckoned with.
He needs to be killed.
No. He's an elemental force. Them you don't destroy. But them and use them for the good they give off. He hands Bill a sack of coal.

Coal? Bill doesn't answer. He HOPS DOWN off the moving wagon, a way quickly before him, then regroup and SWARM after Twee The Boss continues with his Tammany spiel-enjoying all th the Butcher watches, disdainful of Tweed but filled with frustration. From his face we ...

text: ... the incredulous face of Monk Eastman, as he looks at
And this is your offer?
It's Boss Tweedls offer.
How do you think we'd sit as allies, Bill?
The only way we could tolerate being near each other woul out dead.

My thoughts exactly. Then why are you here? Because you w You were ordered to be. And who would order me among the would you follow my orders, even if they was being relaye Marcy Tweed himself? He EASES himself out of the barber chair. The Butcher TEN toward him.

Dubious and doubtful, my friend. But your offer--pardon, bring--is the most generous that's ever been extended. I if not the personalities. So let us decide the way any Na would appreciate. We'll do it the democratic way. He throws open the door of the barber shop and stands the the Butcher, his arm thrown carelessly around him. PASSER wonderment as Monk ADDRESSES them.

Citizens of the Five Points! It seems the Native American trouble. They have grown so weak that now they seek my he any wage I ask. But I ask you now. Even for money, should conspire alongside a boyo like this with gristle on his k on his chin every time his cock gets hard? Monk is beaming, the Butcher is appalled. His body tenses ready to spring. But the people in the street just STARE- believe what they've just heard.
(to Bill) There. You see. I'm afraid the people have spoken.
I'll see you again, you bog Irish bastard.

Well, if it's a fight you want now, Bill, remember to com bankroll. Monk returns to the shop and the comfort of his chair. Bi people in the street. One lock from him starts them movin do not look away from him quite so fast, or at him, eithe same fear.

The vast main room has been changed into a dance floor an the evening. An altar has been hung with bunting; SHIP'S CANDLES illuminate the place. The REVEREND SHADRACH RALEI everyone. The room, already crowded with CELEBRANTS of al quiet as the Dead Rabbits, done up in their party best, s revelry.
Ah, the Native Americans, is it now?
Are they coming?
We don't want a ruckus, minister.
Nor do I. I intended no disrespect. I'd heard the Native figures of the greatest prominence here.
Indeed they are, just for the moment. Let them come. Happ Everyone's welcome in a house of God, isn't that right, R
As all are welcome in heaven.
Ild like to go to heaven. Ild like to go to heaven and bi ear.
You're still welcome, even with such peculiar appetites.
But if the Natives do come, Father...
I'm not a priest, son ...
... there's no accounting for what may follow.
I'm sure God's hand will guide us in that. Just as He gui the right perfect time, with a right perfect regent. The the sunset hair. Miss ...
Everdeane. Jenny Everdeane.
Miss Everdeane. Step forward, please. Radiant and curious, Jenny joins the Reverend Raleigh in room.
And the evening's regent chooses her evening's partner. There is much MUTTERING about this from everyone. Someone farting SOUND.

(unfazed) Here we make only joyful noises to the Lord. Under the instruction of the bustling Reverend and his HE skeptically stand away from the Men, who allow themselves into a LINE. The Reverend Raleigh escorts the delighted J that has been placed, by itself, in the center of the roo down, facing away from the rest of the guests. She holds hand.

Now. The men, please. One by one. The first volunteer Reverend Raleigh brings forward is a Mike. There are RUDE COMMENTS as he leads Mike slowly to room, coming up behind Jenny until she can see Mikels fac the mirror. She SHAKES her head.

Next Gentleman, please. More laughing. The BOYS push out one CANDIDATE. Rejected. Now ANOTHER CANDIDATE comes forward. And STILL ANOTHER- J with the composure of a princess. Now it is Johnny's turn. He WALKS slowly across the big r behind Jenny, trying to look confident. The moment is lon tense... until--just once but very decisively-Jenny SHAKE Jenny watches Johnny's face in the mirror. She stays stil walks back to the GANG. Now Amsterdam starts toward the center of the room. He ke fixed on Jenny. Jenny catches Amsterdam's reflection in the mirror. He ST head. Yes. Him. A small BAND strikes up a barely recognizable version of Fortress Is Our God," arranged in waltz time. Jenny rises her arms to Amsterdam. They start to DANCE, a little clum COUPLES join them.
So you accept?
What?
You accept to be my mort and no one else's.
(teasing) No, it's just that I didn't recognize you in the mirror. some of the face the Butcher gave you.
(going along with the joke) It's not the Butcher, it's the dancing. It shifts my face
Maybe you'll look better later. The Reverend Raleigh and his Helpers DASH among the dance LIGHTED CANDLES, which the COUPLES take and hold as they floor.
I will if we're together later. (she smiles) And what about after that? After tonight?
I chose you just for tonight. If that's not good enough I someone else. She takes a candle from the Reverend and holds it so the Amsterdam's face.

I'll have tonight. But after this don't come to me no mor ready. No more. His eyes, in the candlelight, show both his love and his NODS and they DANCE AWAY ... ... losing themselves now among the dancers, all moving a candles. As they dance, their movement becomes SPLIT, SEQ in motion like an old Gjon Mili photograph. Their bodies YELLOW LIGHT ACROSS the screen like the tail of a comet.
In the hallway. JOHNNY stands pressed against a door.
(whispering) Amsterdam. (louder; hissing) Amsterdam!
Who is it?
Me.
Come on in.
I don't want to come in! You come out.
Just a damn minute. AMSTERDAM comes to the door, half-dressed and sleepy. We on the floor inside.
What do you want?
Just before dawn. The streets are empty, the river is qui follows JOHNNY out of the house.
I'm going to fight you.
Oh, Jesus, Johnny, I'm tired. How about sometime else?
Now.
You want to tell me what this fight's over? Is it The But (Johnny turns, determined) Alright, alright. Then tell me why like this?

So when I lose no one will see. And he SLUGS him. Hard. Harder even than he thought he co stumbles, stunned, then pulls himself up. And CHARGES at him down. The two friends PUNCH, WRESTLE, BITE and PUMMEL EACH OTHE extravagant energy that they soon... ... ROLL OFF the pier...

... onto the muddy ground underneath the pier. They LAND SPLASH in the soggy earth, but they keep fighting .... ... as a PACK OF ORPHANS, eyes glinting like night animal wild beasts disturbed in their burrow. Amsterdam has the physical advantage, and more skill. But fury. All the feeling and the frustration rain out of him making the match nearly even. The Orphan Pack watches the fight silently, showing no fa emotion, just an edge of curiosity. Amsterdam HITS Johnny a wicked combination that makes him in the mud. But Johnny will not go down. Amsterdam, hurt stares at Johnny in wonderment.
Satisfied?

Satisfied? It wasn't me that's been dancing and shagging And he pulls himself to his feet and THROWS a roundhouse half-staggers out of the way. The moment throws Johnny of falls in the mud again, this time on all fours. Amsterdam beside him.
Enough. Johnny won't stop: he throws a punch that Amsterdam can s away. But he's too tired too duck; or maybe he's just fed punch and FALLS on his back.
That's it then.
The hell. And he THROWS HIMSELF on Amsterdam. It's more like he rol than anything, but he's on top of him now, hitting him in all he's got left in him.

Goddamn it. Amsterdam HEAVES Johnny off and pops him a solid SWIPE to does it. Lights out. Johnny falls unconscious into the sl pier. The Orphan Pack keeps staring from the shadow with their Still silent. Amsterdam STRUGGLES to his feet, stops at t to get a handful of water to revive himself. Then he look unconscious friend.

Goddamn you anyway. He grabs Johnny's body by the shoulders and pulls him to He gets some water on his hand, lets it drip over Johnny' away a little of the blood. Not enough. He draws some mor it gently onto Johnny's face. CLOSE: on the motion of his hand. It is nearly gentle.

text: As Don Whiskerandos' hand, holding a razor, travels over of Monk Eastman's face. His hand is shaking.

Come out with it then. Bill NODS emphatically at Don Whiskerandos, who is clearl nods again, almost vehemently. Don Whiskerandos SHAKES hi GLARES at him. The Barber takes a STEP BACK. Monk opens h to size up the situation.
You damn craven, do it! Bill LEAPS forward, grabs the trembling barber's arm and MONK...

He FALLS, still GRABBING desperately for the ... who now stands over him, beating him incessantly with CAVING his head in. KILLING him.
