If I was you I'd use that to open in a new location. Cons The enormity of what he's done is beginning to sink in. H the shop ... but STOPS in the doorway. Outside, CITIZENS of the Points are staring at the fallen wonder. They have just witnessed a moment in history. Bill the Butcher surveys them all silently, then calls ou Whiskerandos.

The war club. The barber steels himself to CARRY the bloody club to the hefts it slowly in his hands, in view of all. He takes a knife from his vest, and CUTS the LAST NOTCH i slowly... ... he steps down into the crowd, which PARTS before him. walks among them in regal splendor, the war club at his s gore. As the crowd falls back, Bill spots Amsterdam, Johnny and other Dead Rabbits, watching his every mave. He STOPS. HOLDS OUT the bloody war club in front of him... straight him... POINTING IT right at Amsterdam.
I promise you, Amsterdam. I promise you. Then he grins, turns away and walks through the crowd: pr surveys.

Boss Tweed reigns in the banquet room of a vast, gaslit r long table overburdened with food. Seated along both side an array of the city's POWER BROKERS, with whom Tweed and MINIONS mix easily. Their attitude toward the Power Broke of ribald fawning and fine condescension; the Power Broke enjoy the food, and the MUSIC from a small BAND, and the flirt and entertain them, while exuding the unmistakable amateur anthropologists exploring a decaying civilization Tweed is courting and joking with a bewhiskered HORACE GR the influential Tribune.
I may enjoy the bounty of your table and the pleasures of Mr. Tweed ...
And the pleasures of the company provided you, Mr. Greele
...without the Tribune endorsing your politics.

I suppose you can at that. Take with one hand, flay with Virtuels on your conscience, Horace, but Tammany's in you Killoran materializes at Tweed's side and whispers someth discreetly in his ear. Tweed EXCUSES himself, rises quick across the restaurant floor... ... past the Band and the Dancing Giris ... ... to the swinging doors of the kitchen. As he pushes op DOOR, his face has lost its humor.

A madhouse of activity. WAITERS in black suits, vests and STREAM by carrying huge TRAYS of food while the KITCHEN S double-time to keep up with the unceasing volume. As Boss Tweed walks in, Bill the Butcher PLUCKS a piece o off a tray as it's carried out the door.
I'm not good enough for your table, so I eat where I can. bite) It's good, what is it?
Pheasant.
Is that like pigeon? I killed a pigeon once but it didn't like this.
You killed a bull this morning. I told you to make an Arr him, and you come back with his blood on your hands.
(chewing his food) He insulted me. He aggravated me. I couldn't stand for th
You stand for anything if I tell you.
You think I should be afraid of you. You act like lightni you talk. As they talk, and the tension builds between them, the tw constantly BUFFETED by the swinging doors and the unendin WAITERS.
I never was afraid of you, so don't think I was or act li ain't earned it.
What did you earn us, killing Monk?
Where'd you earn the right to ask that question? You rais the streets a while back, but no more. You got power but muscle and you ain't got a notion what it means to be a w
I see it lost you a lot of God's sense, along with that e

You don't know nothing about that! It was my doing! It sa "If thy eye offend thee, pluck it out." I followed that l knife and hand. The first I ever fought Priest Vallon, he when he came to bring me to death, I looked away and he w let me go. The shame was worse than the killing. I would eyes if I could still have fought, but cutting just the o When I killed Priest Vallon, that restored me. Now I sent over I got glory. I got all there is, and small thanks to

(measured, conciliatory) You need two eyes to see the dep how we help each other. If it wasn't for me would be happ plunder the Points and put the fear into people who don't else. But Bill, I'm only saying... I'm counselinm... look You want to sit at my table, fine. But you must always re host is. It's not a matter of courage welre talking. It's Bill grabs another piece of food from a tray.
Howls these manners?
Fine, if you're hungry.
I'm always hungry.

I've always told you, Bill. There's plenty for all, and m together than separate. We'll dine together sometime. Bill the Butcher nods, appeased, and leaves, swaggering h the kitchen chaos, making everyone get out of his way. Bo him go, his expression changing from bemused appeasement
Later. Everyone's gone except some WAITERS, cleaning up, and Daniel Killoran, who sit at the end of the banquet ta plates of food have been massed at Tweedls place and, as PICKS from them.

Let me put this to you, Daniel. Now that the Butcher has most prominent figure in the Five Points--a man of myth a there to take his place? (as Killoran starts to answer) Of course. Then what do we do about the Butcher? He's too killed, but he must be checked.
It could be a police matter.

Impossible! Any cops who might have the mettle to go agai have blood ties to the gangs. They can't be trusted. And be trusted are too craven to be any use. If Bill's to be come from within the Points, not without.
The Dead Rabbits did a proud job for elections. That Amst sand.
That so? The last time I saw him he was under the Butcher like a fine filet. Who else is there?
Well, the Rough and Tumble Boys over to Slaughterhouse Po Country McCleesterls bunch, too, and the Plug Uglies, but that have the promise of the Dead Rabbits, or the stake,
What would that be?
The boy Amsterdam has a blood feud with the Butcher. He's for the death of his father, and he's got the heart to ca He'll have the skill and power soon enough.
Blood will make a man intrepid. Bring them along, then. N Rabbits with neglect. Let them roam where they like.
And if they roam into some portion of our own revenues?
I'd tolerate a little trespassing if it was for a higher They'll cross with the Natives soon enough and keep each
Bill's got to be a lot more than occupied.

I'll hold Bill in check. If he becomes unwieldy ... well, Daniel, I might just have to oil up my old musket. What d that, eh? Boss Tweed gets up from the table. A WAITER is DIMMING th filling the room with deep shadows.
It'd be gratifying, Mr. Tweed. Even edifying.
But poor politics, eh? Well, we musn't have that. (as he walks away) I do miss those roistering days, though. Oh, and bring so for the canaries.

The sharply-angled turn of Doyers Street, nicknamed "The SOUND of a horse and cart as we see a row of UPTURNED mos YOUNG CHILDREN. A NATIVE AMERICAN drives a cart carrying large barrels of NATIVE rides beside him on the seat, holding a rifle, loo at the faces turned up to him. A WOMAN holding a BABY in CHILD by the hand steps in front of them. They almost run
We ain't had no milk this week.

You can have as much as you can pay for. (to crowd) Anyone that's got the ned, step up with your pitchers. An when you do. The Woman gives her children to other WOMEN in the crowd toward the wagon. Native 2 cocks his rifle... ... and Jenny steps from the watchful Crowd.

I got ned enough for all. See? Fair enough? She holds her hand out as she WALKS slowly toward the mil carrying a huge fistful of GLEAMING COINS. The Natives on her warily... ... and are JUMPED from behind by a couple of Dead Rabbit grabs a milk pitcher from a WOMAN in the crowd, AXES open milk barrel and FILLS the pitcher to overflowing. Jenny J wagon seat.
(to Amsterdam) What's our rate? What do we charge?
Johnny worked it out to a nickel less than the Natives. J established. Then we raise it a penny more than now.
Raise it? Is that what you want?
You say, then.
(beat; then, to Crowd) There'll be no paying at all this week, neither. This is Dead Rabbits business from now on. The Crowd scrambles for milk and the Rabbits try to keep
(to Crowd) We'll take ned if you got it, now or in future. But no on
(to Jenny) Except us. You opening a charity?
They'll pay us what they owe, in loyalty if not in cash. coal, we give milk.
They can afford it.
Can't we?

The midday sun shining through the windows makes the plac slightly desperate: this is a place that needs low light to look good. Amsterdam and Johnny are at a long bar, talking to Mother wised-up woman with pornographic tattoos an both forearms
This place is so clean it's the next thing to chaste. And convent, too.
From the Natives, maybe. But not from us.
You're saying I got to worry about your mob too?

No worries at all. You throw in with the Dead Rabbits and about the Natives. Across the room, Jenny is sitting talking to a few of the whom is a mixed-blood Eurasian with long black hair named gets up lazily and heads for the bar. As she passes a DRU out to grab her. She's used to this, and she knocks his h keeps after her. At the bar, Mother Joyce notices Emma being hassled, but attention: her girls can take care of themselves.
(to Amsterdam and Johnny) And if someone else comes along, do I pay them too?
You only pay us. We see you safe from everyone. Johnny has been watching the drunk bothering Emma Loss. W anything to Amsterdam or Mother Joyce, Johnny LEAVES the to the drunk and SHOVES him away.
Leave off her. She don't want you. Not even if you could
Hey, just a minute.
(to Emma) He can't pay. I can pay.
(watching this) Maybe I should offer Johnny as a bouncer for your busy ni
(laughs) A bouncer! I don't know if he could bounce on a feather b be a character like you, is that it?
He's got his own ideas. Too full of Tammany, maybe, but h Across the room, Johnny is talking to Emma Loss. She NODS LEAD him upstairs.

But in my trade you go on your instincts. My instincts sa and my memory of your father says I'm right. We'll shake (Amsterdam grabs her hand) And have one of my best to seal the bargain. Megs! A lanky blonde, seated across the room near Jenny, bestir
Come here and show my new friend why we're worth special Jenny watches MEGS move toward Amsterdam.
Big enough to contain a half-gutted mattress supported by some worn sheets and a few GUTTERING CANDLES. Johnny undresses as Emma sits on the bed and starts to ta
You liked that old man? You would have gone with him?
I like anyone that pays, that's all.
Tell me what he wanted you to do.
He mostly wanted comforting.
I never seen hair so black. Can you take the pins out?
It takes so long to do back up. He sits beside her and starts slowly, almost tenderly, to
Did your mother have the same color? I don't know.
(as the hair cascades over her bare shoulders) Lie back, I want to look at you. (his eyes glide along her body) What's that mark?
I always had it.
(touching her lightly) And there? Is that a scar?
(she looks at her naked belly) There was a baby. They cut it out.
And that on your shoulder? That looks old.
Yeah, I got that when I ...
(interrupting, quiet) I don't want to know when. Don't tell me about before or be, I don't want that.
What about your scars. Do you have scars?
None I ever seen. Maybe you can find them. Her hands and mouth cover his body. He closes his eyes.
Another room. Amsterdam and Megs are undressing each othe walks in.
Go on. I can see you later. Megs leaves, brushing past Jenny.
What are you doing?
I couldn't decline what Mother Joyce offered. It's in the business. You understand business.
Sure I do. But there's something else I still don't under Sparrow's Pagoda, did you hit me, knowing it was me?
Yeah. I did. She HITS him. In the face. Hard. Not a slap. A solid PUNC starts to gush blood. He puts his arm under it to staunch keeping his eyes an her.
Meantime's over.
Oh fine. That's fine. I'd be celebrating but I'm losing t Jenny tears part of the sleeve from her blouse and puts i nose.
Put your head back.
That don't work.
Put your head back I said.
(as she tends to him) So why so sudden, then?
Sudden? Every day I see you and you complain I can't deci you say it's sudden.
It's the whore did it, then.
Don't flatter yourself.
It's because you're jealous.
It's because you didn't lie about hitting me.
Christ, I wish I had. Come here, then. He reaches to pull her down on the bed.
Not here. There's too much past.
The room where Johnny fetched Amsterdam out for the fight Jenny have just made love.
It must be morning.
I don't care, I'm not getting up.
This is what you meant, then? It's going to be just the s
What?
Every morning I wake up next to you.
Or you don't wake up at all.
We only just started in and you're already threatening me
It's not a threat. (no teasing now) It's a declaration of love.
I prefer my kind. This kind. She reaches beneath the pillow and pulls out a fine DIAMO she slips on his finger. Amsterdam reacts with surprise, course) suspicion.
What's this? Where'd you get this?
You said I was the best thief in the Five Points. But I g restless. Will you wear something I got?

A long street of tree-shaded houses. Spacious lawns. Nort Points. Considerably north. This is the first time we hav the Five Points and Paradise Square. The city rent place. Jenny and Amsterdam stand near a residence at the end of Amsterdam, dressed in a suit, can't quite conceal his won staring at the house.
What is this place?
My jeweler's. She GESTURES for him to follow her and we see now that sh maid's outfit.
Come on.
I don't see nobody.
That's the best time. They're all having lunch.
At the back door of the grand house, as Jenny OPENS it sl inside.
You're off your head.

(pleased, showing off) You can wait on me a minute. Or I'll see you back in the scared. (Amsterdam looks at her) Don't worry. I know every house on this street. They all open. They live like they're not in New York. She GOES IN the house. Amsterdam WATCHES through the wind going up stairs. Then he looks at the dining room, visibl through an open kitchen door. He WATCHES, fascinated, fragments of the everyday rituals never seen. As SOUNDS drift listlessly from the street be BREEZE blows, WE SEE IN A SERIES OF DISSOLVES the serving SERVANTS carrying and passing plates; FAMILY MEMBERS reac and passing them; the LOW KURMUR of Konversation in accen heard. It's not so much that these people and their life him. It is as if he has stepped into another Dimension. He loses his sense of time, and of danger. So that when J arm she surprises him thoroughly.
Come on. I might still be taken for a maid. But you're no a butler.
As Jenny and Amsterdam walk away from the house. She hold look young and full of hope, like a servant couple just o country enjoying a day off.

The Police Commissioner lives the next street over. I was visiting him next month, but cops don't buy goods. They k graft in cash. Amsterdam looks at the houses with wonder that he tries t She opens her satchel a little way, then NUDGES him to ha swag inside.
How's that for ten minutes?
It's a lot to fence.
I'm not going to fence it. I'm going to keep it and take will recognize it.
Where would that be?
Somewhere west. Far west. Past the Mississippi River, som territory.
That's a hard journey for a woman alone.
You'd be with me.
You got it all planned and straight, is that it?
Once I said I'd be with you I wanted someplace we could b Someplace better than here. What's the matter with that?
Nothing. Except there's no place but here for me right no settle things.
Yeah, I know, but I'm talking about settling down, not se
You don't have my obligations.
The Dead Rabbits SWEEP across the bustling square, Johnny the lead.
It's a fair day's wage. We just move the people out of th collect.
Who from?

Who owns the building. (points) Them. The gang approaches a tumbledown BUILDING called Jacob's the iron rungs that run straight up its front to the roof well-dressed GENTS stare at the building fretfully.
(to Johnny) I'm glad you came in force. There's half a hundred people
Maybe more.
And not one's given rent the whole year.
You live here?
No, no, of course not.
I mean in the city. A ways north, I'll bet.
Yes. Why? A RIFLE SHOT sounds from an upper window and a Rabbit fal all DUCK FOR COVER.
It's not just citizens in there?
Of course it is.
with arms?
From their damned gang. Some of them live there.
Some of who?
The Native Americans.
We didn't contract for that.
We'll pay extra for the danger.

No danger. But you will pay extra. (turns; to gang) Let's go and greet some Natives. Under SCATTERED RIFLE FIRE and a barrage of ROCKS, the GA building, charging inside and starting up the ladder as i attacking a medieval fortress. ARMS reach out from window them off. The Rabbits respond with knives and PISTOL SHOT inside, the CAMERA RISES to an OVERHEAD shot and we ...

Later. The same OVERHEAD ANGLE. BODIES litter the street dead and wounded Rabbits lie near NATIVES who have gone t Some BUILDING RESIDENTS wander the street in a daze. JOHN money from the Two Gents, who look very pleased as Amster with Jenny. He's carrying a rifle he took from the buildi
(to Gents) Alright, then?
Very much alright. Quite a spectacle.
Oh really? Just the entertainment you favor, is it? Pardo moment, gents. (he turns to Jenny) You wanted to settle, you and me. That's so, isn't it? Yo you not.
I did, yes.
Good, because I didn't want to act hasty. I can never tel you're thinking, and sometimes I'm not always sure what y
(interrupting) Excuse me, we have to finish and...
(to Gent 2) Excuse me. We'll conclude in a moment. (back to Jenny) Where do you settle?
Amsterdam, what are you saying?
I'm asking, where does anyone settle?
I don't know, you mean a place, a home?
A home yes.
Excuse me, but we really must conclude.

(ignoring him) Well, I'm saying to you then, Jenny Everdeane, welcome ho No one sees it coming. Amsterdam FLASHES around, swinging rifle into Gent l's midsection, doubling him over and sen breathless to the ground. Amsterdam SPINS again and swing Gent 2's face, knocking him cold.
Fine place. Room enough for all. (to Johnny) Get them out of here.
They'll come back looking for you.
With whose help? The Natives? They won't help these flour even for ned. (to Jenny) Tell any who wants they can stay. If they can't pay rent gang. But make sure the best rooms go to us. Look around
(interrupting) I know this building.
As Jenny leads Amsterdam through a narrow tunnel. The pla weird catacomb: it is narrow and dank, filled with bones of the two- and four-legged variety.

These lead all under the Square, into the Brewery and out there. They're closed off and forgotten since the Reveren mission. Pass me the candle. Amsterdam hands Jenny a stump of candle, which she holds see... ... that the tunnel has opened onto a small room just abo of Jacob's Ladder. It's a graveyard, memorializing gang m better world--or worse. Trophies from many gangs--includi skulls of some Dead Rabbits-litter the place in loose rit if this were a catacomb in Palermo. Stooping low, Jenny walks to a narrow corner of the room, PAVING STONES have been laid in the rough pattern of a cr slate serves as a headstone, and on it, in fading paint, is the name "Maggie Everdeane."

We lived in this building till she lost her seamstress wo the Brewery. One day she slept so drunk she never woke an back here. Dug this myself. (beat) Families. Give here what I gave you. Amsterdam hands her a chest that looks like a small versi Blackbeard's treasure box. She opens it and holds the can is the swag from all her cat burglaries. There's a lot of with promise in the GUTTERING flame. Jenny starts to dig grave.
She'll keep an eye on this for us. How about some help? He KNEELS beside her and they dig at the grave with stone
You trusting me with your treasure, then?
Just take another look at it to remind you. I can always Amsterdam reaches inside the chest, pulls out a ring and Jenny's dirt-covered finger. She KISSES him.
What's mine is yours, is that it?
I could use this, too. From the bag he holds up a small GOLD CROSS.
You making an offering to the Reverend Raleigh? Amsterdam slips the cross into his pocket without answeri dig again.
Are you sure we can trust your mother?
BOSS TWEED listens to an angry BILL THE BUTCHER as they w a long marble corridor lined with formal portraits of for worthies.
The building and how many?
A dozen at least of my Natives.
The Dead Rabbits are a wooly bunch alright.
I want at them. All of them, and Amsterdam especial. Now.

Not just now. It's between too late and too soon. They've too prominent for comfort, but they're still too small fo your hands. The man who killed Monk Eastman pushing aroun upstarts. It's practically undignified.
To hell with any of that. Tweed stops under a grand new PORTRAIT of himself.
Very well, and to hell as well with any plans you and I m growth and change and even greater reward. You'll never a beyond the limited perimeter of your imagination.
I don't got to advance anywhere further.
Got to, no. But ought to. He hands him a fancy embossed envelope.
What's this?
(eyes merry) An invitation. To dinner.

head_text.subj: INT. JENNY AND AMSTERDAM'S ROOM/JACOB'S LADDER DAY

text: Better by a little than their place in the old hideout. T window that throws some LIGHT an the few bits of castoff room... an the bed where Jenny sleeps with her face turne light... and an Amsterdam, who is dressing quietly in the checks in his coat Pocket,...finds the gold cross ... and does nat stir.
START CLOSE on: Amsterdam's hand, as he places the gold c hole at a grave site, then covers it over with dirt. Then WE SEE: Amsterdam is kneeling at his father's grave.
He never had his own cross. Thanks. Now he STANDS and TURNS. Jenny is half-hidden behind an e

Your touch is light, but as a tracker you work awful heav Now that I met your mother, you should come and meet my f As Jenny starts to WALK towards the grave, we see for the ... that we are in the country, a graveyard in an open fi astonishing PANORAMA of New York and the East River. (MAT is atop a hill, and the East River, busy with ferries and trade, glistens in the near distance. Just beyond it is M low buildings, winding narrow streets, houses surrounded BREEZE off the river rustles Jenny's dress and blows her up to the grave site, looks at the headstone and sees ... ... it is blank. No name, no date. Clean stane.
You should finish the stone.
It'll be finished when everything's finished. That's when hand that killed him is the hand that will bury him in pe He holds up his open hand, covered in dirt.
It was Bill killed him, not you.
With my hand on the knife.
And his hand on yours!
And me feeling the life go out of my father! He looked at at me and he swore me with his eyes. I could feel his spi could feel it rising... flowing through the knife like bl heart.
You talk like he lives in you.
I don't want him to live, I want him dead! I kill Bill an them both!
You think you can be free that easy? You need your way so you''' use anything to clear it. Anyone, too. Me, everybo just a way for you to settle your damned ghosts.
You're part of me now, like the gang is part of me and my I can bring us to glory, then my father... like The Book can enter his house justified. As Amsterdam continues to talk we ...

The growth of the Dead Rabbits, as we continue to HEAR Am passionately to Jenny. We first see the Rabbits surroundi OVERTURNING a fire wagon; this starts as a live action sc BLEEDS into SEPIA, then freezes like an old magazine illu

All of us is set on the same road together. The gang can they ever wanted and get me what I want while they're doi interfering with each other, we're helping each other. It we're all one together. We CONTINUE with sepia illustrations: of Dead Rabbit mort and purses along a crowded Broadway; climbing onto a wago newspapers and tossing off the occupants, taking over the themselves; swarming all over a merchant ship in the harb doles out protection money to have his cargo unloaded.

We'll all have a share of the profit like we'll all have fame. If we come to be notorious, that only means we're s we're strong that means we're ready. A sepia illustration of a fire wagon rounding a corner, r manned by Rabbits, all wearing striking uniforms with sho TAMLAS. (N.B.: they will be seen wearing the tanlas from during all gang activity throuqhout the rest of the film. Amsterdam and Jenny do not wear them.) The sepia illustration turns to live action as the fire w Paradise Square, SCATTERING everyone in its path, the Dea laughing, their tamlas FLYING behind them.

And I'll know that time, know it right off when it comes. you. The live action DISSOLVES TO... ... the last image in the montage: an ILLUSTRATION of Ams half-decade older, turned out in fancy clothes, but with fierceness intact. This is a magazine illustration, and t headline over his picture: "Fresh Scourge of the Five Poi reads "June, 1863.11
And just like that, there'll be no way of stopping till i From this illustration, we quickly...
... Amsterdam, as he is in the picture, but in live actio his feet and YELLING at a couple of PRIZEFIGHTERS doing b

Now! Finish him now! Far up the sparkling Hudson, a RAFT floats slowly upstrea thing (perhaps half a city block in size) crowded with SP form a LARGE RING around two mammoth PRIZEFIGHTERS who ar bare knuckles. Amsterdam and Johnny are among the spectat

Our man will take him in another five. What puts you in s FIGHTER 1 fetches FIGHTER 2 a powerful roundhouse punch t CRASHING to the deck. As soon as he hits the floor, a CAR carrying a sign announcing "Round 37.11 SECONDS drag the 2 to his corner, while two BOYS minister to Fighter 1, SU off his knuckles. A GONG sounds to announce the appearance, in the center o the fight promoter, a florid and fulsome P.T. Barnum .

I want to extend thanks and admiration not only to our tw today, but to their sponsors, the Dead Rabbits ... (indicates one side of the ring) ... and the Native Americans. He FLINGS an expansive arm toward the opposite side of th Bill the Butcher sits with Daniel Killoran and a large gr Amsterdam and the Butcher eye each other with all the old almost ceremonial now, part of the Tradition.

Their generous support allows me to bring you this splend With their indulgence I'd like to remind you also of the that await you at my new Museum, located on Broadway... There are BOOS from the crowd at such untoward commercial

... P.T Barnum's gallery of wonders from worlds natural a from nature and from myth! (continued boos) And to encourage you also in the view that new Albany ord forbidding sportive violence on land shouldn't dampen you wagering. Bets down, entlegen, and you gents.. (indicated fighters) ... fists up! The Fighters come to center ring, circle each other, then A flurry of punches, and Fighter 2 GOES DOWN again. As he the round automatically ends and the between-rounds ritua again.
Dobbs will take him this round. That'll be something. The never lost before.
Because there's never been a Dead Rabbit fighting before.
That'll shame them thorough.
There'll be worse than shaming. We only got the Natives i It's time to squeeze the trigger, John. The next round begins and the Fighters set to, MAULING ea furiously.
Don't push the Natives too far, Amsterdam. Otherwise it'l pushing back.
That don't matter any more.

It does matter, and it's going to matter even more. Tamma and future of this city. If the Rabbits is going to keep going to have to throw in with Tammany some way. The action in the ring is FURIOUS. The Crowd cheers. Figh to go down, but recovers and starts returning punishment
They got that Conscription Act from Washington keeping th won't leave us alone forever. And the Natives is strong a In the ring, Fighter 1 drives Fighter 2 to the deck again KNOCKS HIM COLD.
(indicates Fighter 1) You call that strong, John? In the ring, a couple of agitated NATIVE AMERICANS are tr the Rabbit-sponsored winner. RABBITS start to RUSH the ri WAVES them back.
(to Johnny) This is our time now!

(trying to make official announcement) The winner... gentlemen, please! ... the winner in the 39 Dead Rabbits champion, High Water Dobbs ... please, gentl The unofficial ring COMBAT continues, knocking Barnum abo champ throws marauding Natives around like empty flower s iumps into the fray, PUSHES some Natives away. They start champ stands them off while Amsterdam WHISPERS to Barnum.

Just a moment, please, gentlemen! There's a word for us a promises ... (Amsterdam whispers to him briefly) ... something large, something grand, something epic. The are my own words, of course the greatest righting of the ever done in the Five Points. The crowd quiets, their sporting blood still up, curiosit Johnny seems glum, concerned. This is to be a duel not for money, but for honor! A figh
(interrupting, emphasizing) To the death. If he can stand up to it.
... on which money, I hasten to add, may certainly be wag of the two champions are Amsterdam Vallon, here beside me William Poole, known to all as ...

(leaping up) They know me by any name, you son of a bitch! The crowd ERUPTS: this is a death match between Olympians does not rejoice. He looks at Amsterdam's face, flush wit the right moment has finally come, and he has to turn awa from the ring as Killoran tries unsuccessfully to PULL th and cool him off.
(yelling) I'll have him stretched on a spit! Killoran is beside him now, whispering urgently. Bill the his head vehemently.
(to Killoran) You got no more to say about this now.
Come on, Bill! Let go of your Tammany wet nurse! My chall
(to Bill) Don't do it, you can't do it! There's the Conscription to elections coming, too. That's your calling now, not these

I'll do my work. But this is a shame, a public shame. It attention. (yelling to Amsterdam) Fine, then! Fine and welcome! Day after elections, we'll on neutral ground to work out time and terms. It will be He walks to the ring, holds his HAND out to Amsterdam.
You know this hand. Last time it was this close, it was o
I remember it better from another time. He takes the Butcher's hand. The duel is on.

START CLOSE ON: money being counted out: $300. And a RECE written and given. We think at first this must be a bet b duel between Amsterdam and Bill the Butcher- But we go WIDER to reveal: an office, tables and chairs, lines, in fact. One, very long, filled with young man. An very short, in which a CLERK is handing the receipt to a MAN.
Your release from service, according to the terms of the Keep it somewhere safe.

I'll keep it with me. There is only one OTHER PERSON standen behind the Prosper and he steps up quickly and hands $300 to the Clerk as th Young Man heads for the door... ... past the second line, which snakes out into the stree draftees who SHOUT at the Prosperous Young Man as he leav
Hey, tell your Papa to pass me three hundred dollars too.
Tell him if he don't we'll come get you on our way to Get The Prosperous Young Man HURRIES away, but spots Boss Twe Killoran as he leaves.
Oh, Mr. Tweed, I'd take the time to say proper thanks but

No thanks owed, son. Conscription's Federal Law, and so's exemption. You might remind your father, though, that you today, minding that the law's strictly and equitably enfo The Prosperous Young Man hurries out, as the Draftees con abuse. Boss Tweed HEADS for them, followed by Killoran.
You see how much they like this damned law? Enforcing it' us in elections.
It's not my law, and not my liking, either. But Washingto treated us with sufferance, and we must extend the same r (to Draftees) Boys, we are bound by honor and love of country to fight crisis!
We're bound by our wallets and the emptiness in them, tha
Boys, the union is in distress, our land is wounded deepl suddenly a frail and finite thing. We must ask ourselves
Yeah, you could talk a dog off a meat wagen, Tweed. But l fight!
That'd be worth twice three hundred dollars to see!

(as he backs off) Thank you, boys, thank you for your understanding. (to Killoran) Holy Mother. Tweed hustles Killoran outside, where the line of Potenti snakes down the block and into Paradise Square.

Daniel, between the blindness of Washington and the damne Poole Tammany will fall like an autumn leaf. We must take can. Attend to the Butcher. After the elections, of cours think Amsterdam will do our work for us first.
He could at that. Then he would become a fresh concern

Not so daunting as this. (turns to the Draftees in the street) Boys, I've just had a word with your compatriots inside, half the sand and a fraction of the spirit they have mani this great struggle... There is a chorus of BOOS and JEEPS from the Draftees out
Put a rope around it, Tweed, and swing in your own wind!
Great weeping Jesus, Daniel, whatever happened to the hal

Election Day pandemonium. The Dead Rabbits aren't working this day, but Johnny observes the action as Native Americ because of their long dusters--strongarm REPEATERS into t His attention is drawn to a HARRIED TELEGRAPH OPERATOR, w SHOUTED at by Natives as he is inundated by pieces of pap volumes of the voting registry. It's chaos. The poor Oper
It's chaos here, too. The large main room is filled with OPERATORS receiving election returns. There is SHOUTING a throughout the room. Even Boss Tweed shows signs of worry
I swear that science will be the death of industry.
The telegraph moves the voter tabulation by wire faster t the repeaters in and out.
(losing patience) Your role is to expedite, Daniel, not to explain. (Killoran looks at him blankly) Do something!
If you'll allow me. They both TURN to see Johnny standing coolly before them.
There's a scheme we might try.
You got no place among us, get the hell out of here howev
A moment please, Daniel. One moment. (to Johnny) You're a Dead Rabbit, aren't you? Friend to Amsterdam? (Johnny nods) And therefore no particular friend to us. What brings you
Opportunity. Science and opportunity.
You got opportunities enough among your own.
I did have. But times change faster than people. Some peo I like to stay with the advantage.
Well, then, a Gentleman of foresight! Are you suggesting. you're even saying... that your friend and your gang may lagging behind the great march of history?
Something like that, yeah.
Well fine, step up to history then and tell us what you h
START CLOSE ON: telegraph wire, HUMMING with the election below it--far below--Johnny, Killoran and a couple of TAM looking up at the wire.
I ain't goin' up there. I got my election suit on.
This election'll be over unless we get up there.
"We?" This was your notion, you go up there.
(looking at polling place) Him. He looks likely, and he ain't workin'. He points over at Sheeny Mike Kurtz, who is observing the polls.
(calls to him) Sheeny Mike, you want to make ... (to Boyo 1) ...how much?
A dollar.
(to Sheeny Mike) Five dollars? Just to help us?
(a bit wary) What's the pitch, Johnny? Amsterdam wouldn't like it, wor
Well, now, if Amsterdam wouldn't like it ...
(interrupting) He knows about it. Welre working a whole new scheme. But youlre helping, if that's the way you want it. And you ca five. Just start climbing.

(beat) Where's the ned? Boyo 2 hands Sheeny Mike five bucks, which he pockets as a large pair of SHEARS. Mike wipes his palms on his pants the pole. For Killoran and the Tammany Boyos, this is like a circus watch Mike's ascent with pleasure. Sheeny Mike is quite pleased with himself as he nears the He turns to look at Johnny and the Tammany group below. A SPECTATORS have stopped to watch as well. Mike gets to the top of the pole, REACHES OUT--STRETCHES telegraph wire with the shears... ... strains... reaches ... MAKES THE CUT. On the ground, Johnny looks relieved. The Boyos offer a p of applause. In the spirit of things, Sheeny Mike TURNS to acknowledge Just briefly. But long enough so he's distracted. He sees FACES fill suddenly with fear, and he TURNS when he HEA.R WHISTLING NOISE. A LIVE TELEGRAPH WIRE is coming at him. He doesn't even h scream. The wire hits him, whipping around him as JOLTS O his body and he FALLS to the ground.
HANDS pick up the lifeless body of Sheeny Mike and start off... past Amsterdam and Jenny, who stand on one side of and Johnny, who is on the other.
He was working a Tammany job, Tammany will see to him.
He wasn't Tammany. Not like you.
He made the right choice.
You don't know what you're saying! You killed one of our family!

(slowly) I didn't know he was going to die, Amsterdam. And don't t own and what isn't. You're not my family. And I swear, I Virgin Mother's eyes ... I know what I'm doing, Amsterdam always been blind. (they look at each other) I'll say my farewells. Johnny KNEELS down beside Mike's body, brushes the hair f
You still smell like drink. He nods to the Rabbits to carry the body on and, as he RI NEWSBOYS DASH into the square, carrying fresh copies of t crying...
New Tammany victory! Fernando Wood elected to third term! prevails by narrow margin! Boss Tweed vows Armageddon for crime!
(looking at Amsterdam and Jenny) Can't you hear the future? He walks away from the gang, through the rushing Newspape
The place has been cleared out for a war council: Amsterd of Dead Rabbits, and Bill the Butcher with a few Natives. round poker table with a green felt top.
We say the Square is the place. Let Barnum sell the ticke the price...
(interrupting) A small share.
And the Rabbits and Natives will split the majority porti
Who works the crowd?
Nobody. This is a day of honor. No pickpockets, no lush-r
I'll cut their hands off. After the fight.

We got to fix positions for everyone so there won't be no I know for fact the Roach Guards has sworn blood against and the Forty Thieves don't tolerate the Chichesters. As these delicate negotiations continue, the only two out place, Mother Joyce and a Bartender, are listening intent side of the room.
Amsterdam will make the Butcher a fine banquet.
My ned's on the boy. He's got the youth, and he's got the
Is he so hungry you'll put up a hundred?
Two.
OFFICIALS stand on a high wooden platform facing a JEERIN announce a "DRAFT LOTTERY." OFFICIALS are preparing to dr numbers as Boss Tweed gives out with a speech.
Your honor... yes, and the law of the land... lies in the Conscription Act of 1863 was handed down by President Lin
(shouting) If Lincoln signed it, then let Lincoln fight!
It's an army of the poor fighting for a bunch of rich sla

Tammany's been our voice, let Tammany pay the exemption f A YOUNG MEMBER of the crowd steps forward as Boss Tweed t those backing him on the platform: Killoran, a CAVALRY OF dress ... and, out of sight of the crowd, Johnny Sirocco. expressions are not reassuring.

Your first payment, m'lords. The Young Crowd Member hurls a STONE through the front wi store. The CROWD cheers and runs to sack the store, and o toward the platform. Johnny'and Killoran grab a fearful T to safety. But the Cavalry Officer stands his ground with pistol. He SHOOTS. That STOPS them. But only for a fractured, eerie moment. the Cavalry Officer, PULL him to the ground, begin to KIC

A building burns at the end of the street, spreading a si and flame in the air... ... as a LION CHARGES down the street, growling, scatteri wake. It's a mad, frightening sight, like a fulfillment o prophecy produced by P.T Barnum, whose Museum is burning SCREAMS, YELLS, CURSES and GROANS. CRIES of pain and fear out of the way of the wild animal, then course up the str Broadway burning in the distance. From ABOVE, on the roof of Jacob's Ladder, Amsterdam and madness below.
(watching lion) That must be the vanguard of Barnum's army.
This city will burn like Gomorrah.
Then we'll take what we can before it gets too hot.
I think it's past that already.
It'll never come to that. These people ain't gang-led and purpose. They'd rather die for themselves than the army, that's th would you do?
Fight better and not get so mad. They're only doing what done years ago. Why'd they ever think there was another w
They believed what people told them, that's all.
What people is that? The Reverend at the mission? Boss Tw Killoran? People like Johnny Sirocco?
You believed Johnny.
Hell.
And I believed you.
I ain't done nothing different than what I told you, Jen.
I believed what you said abaut being with me, with me alo to me. It's not me alone, it's just you and Bill Poole. Y blood-blind you can't see nothing else, not even this!
I don't care a fine damn about what they want! It's what won't dare harm the Points, that's all I care about! Let rest of the city into hell! It's another country anyway.
It's not a country for me, Amsterdam. I don't know about come with me?
Not now.
Now is when I'm going. Will you come?
I don't want all this fighting to go to waste, Jen. I wan it with something. And I got to be waiting for the Butche
Jenny digs out her treasure from her mother's grave, thro starts to GRAB all the swag she can and hide it on her pe pockets, under her clothes, anywhere. She takes as much a she has to travel fast.

Beginning a swift series of scenes that are like a laudan The street is JAMMED with people fleeing and people fight forces her way through, trying to escape. A small mob starts to ATTACK a house where a TERRIFIED FA the doorway.
We're with you, don't harm us!
Show us your spirit and come out with us then!

And put a candle in the window to show you're one with us a flame against the draft! The WIFE begs her husband not to join the mob, but they P the street. The Mob Woman hands the Wife a candle, then r the mob. Jenny starts to cross Paradise Square now... tries to cro passes the stand where Tweed delivered his speech that ve sees: the Cavalry officer. Several MOB WOMEN have revived He has been beaten terribly, but as he MOANS and starts t consciousness, the MOB WOMEN fall upon him with fresh fur HITTING his helpless body. They BREAK his bones with rock the fancy braid of his uniform to hang around their necks Now a SECOND MOB RUSHES toward the first from the opposit Paradise Square. Chaos. Jenny is buffeted wildly. It's li whirlpool. She grabs a LITTLE GIRL whose face is bruised whose eyes shine wildly.
What is it?
Cops has everything closed to the north, and the militia'
As Jenny presses her way through the mob-devoured streets WOMEN and CHILDREN attacking a small group of BLACKS.

My Daddy don't have to die for you! Why should he fight a Jenny looks ahead, sees: the river, in the distance. And forward, STUMBLES. Some of the swag FALLS to the street. pick it up as Rioters rush by her.

MATTE: The surface of the water looks like a mirror made piers are BURNING. The docks are ash. SAILORS battle a MOB for possession of a small rowboat. A boat starts to DRIFT. Jenny spots it, RUNS for it ... but so does ANOTHER GIRL. Younger than Tenny--20 mayb when Amsterdam fell in love with her. They both get to th same time. Each grips it by a gunwale, and they STARE at two jungle beasts over a kill.

I'd kill you for this. The Girl lunges at her with a knite, and Jenny SHOOTS. Th into the flame-reflecting Hudson as if she drowning in a Jenny climbs into the boat and frantically starts to row. her ... working the oars clumsily, furiously ... moving t the water, trying to get away from the city... ... and we go WIDER now. A huge line of IRON--like the si glacier... bisects the frame, then starts to move. Jenny turns, SEES it. It is ... ... the looming hull of an ironclad war ship (MATTE). It into the city, setting off tremendous explosions. Jenny TURNS back for the shore... ... as cannonballs land, devastating rioters.

MATTE: Police and MILITIA push the rioters back toward th rats. A cannanball EXPLODES in their midst... ... injuring many more cops and militia than rioters. The RUN over the bodies of fallen cops and soldiers. Now the theirs; cops and militia are in retreat. Jenny climbs up on shore and joins the mob as it presses

Further from the docks. Shells still exploding in the dis moves with the marauding mob, recognizes Doyers Street. S from the mob, moves stealthily into the street known as t And STOPS. Weird shadows dance on the walls of the buildings. SMOKE The angle is lined with lampposts. And from every lamppos BODY of a black man. Or woman. Or child. Some are still s At the base of a lamppost, a group of RIOTERS have cut op CORPSE of a black man and are pouring oil into it. One of Jenny, grins and holds out the TORCH he's holding. She sh starts to BACK out of the alley. The Rioter touches the torch to the oil in the wound of t body IGNITES in flame. The RIOTERS pull on a rope and the burning, to the top of the lamppost ... ... where its awful shadow joins all the others in the ma refractions on walls all up and down the street. On the s flames dance and the bodies burn, rioters DANCE and SING. From these mad SHADOWS, we...
... the face of Amsterdam, stepping out of the SHADOWS of are flames in the distance. The whole gang is assembled, speaks.
No we ain't going to fight, but we can take something for this.
I want to know who hung them bodies in the Bloody Angle. who done it.
Five thousand people in the street done it! Boss Tweed do Lincoln done it! There's nothing you can do about any one with us. You'll have a little of your own back.
How's that?
These riots are a gift. They... ... he PAUSES just for a moment as he sees a hand on the outside ladder leading to the roof: it's Jenny, returning
... they've made everything clear, as you might say. (to Jenny) Are you with us, then?
Until I can get out. I'll go with you... (straight at Amsterdam) ...meantime.
Good. We're going for the Armory at Canal Street.
The Armory! We'll have to beat the militia to get there.
There's a way through the lines. Jen, did you see the cop
I can show you from here where they are. I doubt they'll in force before midday tomorrow.
We'll get there first. We'll take everything we can carry rest so no one else has the use of it, the militia, the N Then we'll turn to real business. We'll go down to the Ba
Why, we going to take a sail to Europe?
No. But we could, after this. We're going... (slowly, savoring this) ...we're going to take the banks. The government banks. (awed silence from all) Are we not?
(beat; steps forward) Seems we are. One by one, then in small groups, the entire gang FOLLOWS uncertain, reluctant, even frightened at the audacity of they stand with Amsterdam.

The crowded main room of Boss Tweed's domain, jammed with POLITICOS and OFFICIALS, as well as a harried group of TE who receive news of the riots from all over Manhattan. Th of the city against one wall: the place has been converte political princedom to an operational headquarters. Johnn Bill The Butcher are there. Other guests include the GOVE Fernando Wood, and a badly shaken Horace Greeley.
They attacked me! I had every sympathy for them at first.
Too much sympathy, Horace. Writing these riots were a ris "unjust laws and unsuitable law-givers." The shame!
I suspended the draft at noon but the mobs only grew more a criminal rising of the lowest class, of the Gangsters a have been allowed by Tammany to run lawless!
It was Tammany and the rabble that elected you, Governor. and the gangs who'll stop it. Isn't that so, Bill?
(nods at Johnny) I won't say nothin' in front of him. Who knows what busin

He's here on our business and my invitation. He's already help. What's the opposition strength, John? To answer, Johnny yanks back a CURTAIN drawn across a hig view, looking downtown, is one of almost continual ILLUMI place the eye falls, CANDLES burn in sympathy for the rio
Each candle is against you, gents.
"Against you," sir? Don't you mean "us".
(diplomatic) Some of us come from those people, Mayor. I'll not deny t part of me.
Which part? Perhaps your heart.

Gentlemen, I'm sorry you find it necessary to question th friend here, and by extension, my own judgement. So as pr where will the mob go? What will the gangs do? (Johnny is uneasy about answering) Go on, tell them what you told me.
There's no telling about the mob. Or the small gangs. But ... if I was Amsterdam...
(interrupting) As indeed you nearly was. Were.
... if I was ... I'd figure to take the Rabbits to the Ar
Would you agree with that, Bill? Wouldn't you do the same fighting against the militia instead of beside them?
Beside them? What are you talking... ?
(interrupting) You will have to fight beside them to take the Armory. It unfriendly hands.
I can't stand with the militia against the people. I coul Points no more if I did.
We're all of us swept up in a great tide of events, Bill. to swim? From Bill's face, struggling to make sense of this, knowi but not wanting to believe it, we ...
... Johnny's face, as Tweed talks to him. It is later, an left. The activity is still frantic all around, but Tweed unhurried tones.

I'm sure that Bill will do his usual splendid job. But af well, I'm afraid he's grown away from us. (Johnny looks puzzled) He shows distressing signs of... shall we say, free-think flourishes in chaos, and these riots could encourage Bill himself. He no longer inspires in me the same trust... we might. If you can prove yourself further.
You already said in front of everyone you trusted me.
In vital things. Would I be talking to you now otherwise? but small things. Are you equal to greater responsibility
Such as what?

Ridding me of Bill the Butcher. (Johnny is startled) He may question your loyalty to me, but Bill would never the sand to go against him. He'd never expect it. Do you From Johnny's face, struggling to make the right answer,
... Ansterdam's face, as he looks up from preparing a bra the next day's scheme.

Let him in. Johnny enters the common room of Jaccb's Ladder, where th have gathered to ready themselves. As they work over thei prepare battle dress, Johnny walks through their midst. T acknowledge him... except for Jenny.
Did you miss us, John?
Not a bit.
(rising to meet him) Are you here to spy?
I don't have to spy. Amsterdam leads Johnny off to a shadowy corner of the roo talk privately.
(as they walk) I know what you're doing. I told Tweed what you're doing.
You don't know what I'm doing.
You're going after the Armory.
Am I now? Why do you think that?
'Cause that's what I would do, and you and I think alike.
No more. And it don't seem worth a visit to tell me somet think I'm doing.
There's something else alright. Tweed's arranged to kill
(disbelieving) Who could Tweed get to do that?
One of his own.
There's no one around him...
(interrupting) Listen, it don't matter who, it's going to be done, that' ain't going to wait around for you and Bill to settle yourselves. I'm telling you so chance.
Chance of what?
A chance... a chance to do what you want. Bury the Butche blood you got to. But you better make speed. The Natives Armory too.
And what's any of it mean to you?
It means whatever's left of friendship, I don't know. The of me here. I don't want to see you lose everything in your life at once.
I'm going to lose nothing. (beat) If you believe me, you can stay.
I got to go. He turns so Amsterdam can't see his face and LEAVES-
So Tammany's going to kill the Butcher. That puts you and same side. Does that make the path clear enough to suit y From Amsterdam's face, trying to work out all the new ang

... Amsterdam's face, full of resolve, staring unblinking ... the barrels of two dozen RIFLES SURROUND the edges th Amsterdam in, as if his head were in a frame. And Bill the Butcher gazes at him with astonishment. We a time, in the Natives' lair, a house hung with American fl and vintages, some of them torn by battle, others by year use. Some of them go back to the early days of the republ an inch of wood or wall space to be seen for all the star
Murder Me? No one's going to murder me.
Then you better learn to fight locking over your shoulder that's the only way you'll ever see it coming.
I don't believe it, and I don't believe it's you telling reason to care about any danger to me.

One reason. You're my kill, Butcher. No one else is going Tweed, not Tammany, not those pigs in the street. No one- Bill--will ever take the pleasure of your death away from anything to keep you for my own, even if I have to protec
You protect me? Get out of here and go to hell.
Fine, so long as I pass you on my way.
Maybe I'd believe you more if I knew who was talking to y
Someone I credit.
That means nothing to me. None of this means nothing to m Tammany. Without me and my Natives they're nothing but a horses at a trough.

You join with me and we fight against Tammany, fight them the Points. Then you and me can settle. But if you don't then there won't be no settlement because you'll be murde and the whole Points will be mine.
I relish the thought... just the thought... of cutting yo you wide. So if just thinking about it gives me such plea I'm going to enjoy doing it.
Why don't I make it easy for you, then. He TURNS his back on the Butcher and starts to walk out, entire gang of Natives.
Same as you're making it easy for Tweed. He keeps walking... through the Natives ... dozens of anc glowering at him.
Amsterdam! (Amsterdam looks around) Don't be like your father. Don't make it too easy. Amsterdam struggles to keep his temper. But he turns and through the enemy camp as we...

....Amsterdam walking. But this time, he is WALKING among the Dead Rabbits are assembled, weapons ready. Jenny is b Jimmy Spoils. Then a few others. As the group passes, others STAND and walk with them... ... until the whole gang is rallied... ... and bound for the passageway in the corner of the roo under the building.
As Amsterdam and the gang heads through the catacomb-like the graves, into a tunnel. Torchlight GUTTERS all around. like repeated rifle shots.

The whole gang MARCHES down a tunnel under the Old Brewer Amsterdam and Jenny, they all wear their tamlas. Many hav insignia on their faces. All of them have weapons. A lot Frightened FACES--people seeking shelter and safety from in the darkness, then vanish like ghosts. As the Rabbits walk, they summon memories of the first fi march through the tunnels when Amsterdam marched beside h Amsterdam's face gives little away. But perhaps he is rem too.
The last tunnel.. Shreds of light from a door in the dist walks up to the door and--just as Monk Eastman did years down. Dim dawn LIGHT FLOODS the tunnel as the Dead Rabbit

The first thing we see is an ELEPHANT, who trumpets fearf sudden sound of the sattere door. The gang stops, wary of refugee from Barnum's Museum, but the animal is more frig It hurries on down the street... ... revealing behind it a group of several dozen RIOTERS American flag and a long wooden plank bearing the legend stare at the Rabbits with something near reverence.
Where's the Native Americans?
Ain't seen them. Ain't here.
And the militia?
There's a detachment coming on from two streets over. The north of here. What are you after? Amsterdam POINTS to a formidable building a block away: t looks like a fortress.
The Devil himself couldn't take that place.
That's why he sent us.

The DETACHMENT of militia proceeds warily towards the Arm young, uncertain-looking outfit; their COMMANDER looks li farm kid. He tenses and his eyes widen as he sees Jenny w him, carrying a BOY in her arms.
(crying) Help me. Oh please help me. He's shot, we need a doctor,

Miss, we ain't a medical outfit. The main unit's ten minu they'll have... He doesn't get the chance to finish. Jenny DROPS the Boy shoots the Detachment Commander once, cleanly... ... as the Boy roles into a prone position and FIRES two stunned Detachment... ... while the Dead Rabbits SWARM from every doorway along FIRING GUNS and brandishing weapons. It's over in seconds. The Detachment has hardly gotten of one of them lies dead or wounded in the street... ... as the Rabbits CROUCH over their bodies.

A rifle emplacement manned by a dozen GUARDS- They stand front of the Armory. Each window is barred and fortified, door is massive. But the tension in the Guards' faces eas they see ... ... the Detachment of militia heading towards them down t of the Detachment are wearing bloody uniform jackets; sev carried. The Detachment, unrecognized by the Guards, is m of Dead Rabbits.
Help us, we got wounded!
We can't leave the post.
Open the damn doors then! We're bad hurt!
Where's the others?
Just behind us! But I got our major here wounded so bad h out! Guard 1 SIGNALS for the doors to be opened to the Armory draws close to the emplacement.
God, it's good to see you!
Likewise. Ainsterdam SHOOTS him where he stands as the Rabbits OVER emplacement.

(shouting) Move fast! We got to get out with everything we can befor gets here! As the Armory Guards return fire, the Boy Jenny carried i scene RUNS for the telegraph pole and starts to CLIMB. A wood fly inches from his face... ... as the Rabbits storm into the Armory, FIRING wildly. The Boy reaches the top of the telegraph pole and CUTS th shinnies back down the pole as the wire SWINGS ineffectua and we ...
..a telegram, held in Killoran's hand. He passes it to Tw
It's from the Armory Guards. That's the last before the w

(reading, furious) If the Rabbits are already at the Armory, where the hell militia? He THROWS the telegram onto the floor, where it joins a w yellow telegraph forms. They are shin-high; there must be them.
They got to be near.
So long as they're near, it's alright. The Rabbits can ta but they can't hold it. If Bill can get into position, he they don't get out.

Alright then, John, you pray to any God you choose that's If Bill thinks he can best the Natives, that is your oppo your moment. (Johnny hesitates) Are you a Bible man? The Book says in Revelations, "I saw a new earth." If the hand of God's not on you to fulfill then the hand of Tweed will be. Go on and God bless. Johnny looks like he is about to say something, but he st Tweed a moment longer; then nods acknowledgment and leave
I don't believe he can do it, Tweed.

Oh, I think he can. Whether it's one man against another the city, the mathematics remain the same. You never enjo enlightenment of poverty, did you, Governor? If you had, can always hire half the poor to kill the other half.

A TREMENDOUS VOLLEY of GUNFIRE, as if to illustrate the T class warfare. Bodies fall in the street. Bodies fall fro building is under siege by the main unit of the MILITIA a Butcher and the Natives. The Dead Rabbits are trapped. Johnny SNAKES through the Native American lines, over dea towards Bill, who he sees a hundred yards away... ... running over corpses of comrades and enemies toward t COMMADER. As SHOT WIDENS, the carnage is revealed. Bodies their uniform dusters, and Rabbits, in their tamlas, lie the street.
FIRING continues from both sides as the Butcher shouts at Commander.
We move now and we can drive them out! We press them and
I can't spare the men or stand the risk! We stay fast and

Tweed put me in charge of this! I say we move, and by the we will move! (turns to his men) Native Americans, come with me! Any militia that wants to instead of die hunkered down, come with us! Bill STALKS through the lines, rallying the men. And John FOLLOW.

We'll show you gladiators' greatness! Come on! The men start to JOIN the Butcher; even some militia fall through the men gathering near the Butcher. He's closer t Bill starts to mount their BARRICADE. There is MOVEMENT a around him as Natives and militia fall into rough formati to obscure Bill from Johnny's view. Shield him. He has to make his move. NOW. He DRAWS a revolver as mili pass in front of him... he AIMS ... he's anxious, confuse shakes ... he fires... too soon! ... ... and HITS a Native, who falls dead. Right near Bill. The Butcher turns in the direction of the shot, SEES John lock. Johnny FIRES again ... WINGS Bill ... ... and Bill SHOOTS him. Johnny FALLS with the first shot him now, looking down at him.
Was it Tweed or your friend put you to this?
Tweed. Bill SHOOTS him again, point blank. Johnny screams.
You'd lie to save your friend.
(in terrible pain) No. There's no friends for me.
Me the same. Pity us both. He EMPTIES his revolver into Johnny.

(to his men) Hold your fire! (toward the Armory) In there! Hey in there! I want to talk to Amsterdam! The Militia Commander is aghast at this proposition and s gun in hand. But a Native STOPS him. Amsterdam's face APPEARS in a front window of the Armory.
Go on, then, talk.
You and me.

(beat) Come ahead then. And bring my friend's body. Bill the Butcher SLINGS Johnny's body over his shoulder a were an empty sack of flour... ... and starts walking thraugh the lines toward the Armor watches in disbelief, the Natives in confusion. The Dead Butcher in their sights. But no one fires. No one moves. And Bill the Butcher enters the front doors of the Armory

As the Butcher is admitted through the huge doors which c behind him. It's a scene of devastation inside-dozens of everywhere. And enough rifles and munitions to sink Manha Bill the Butcher stands dead center in the middle of the Amsterdam walks toward him. The Butcher DROPS Johnny's bo his feet.
Your friend made different friends lately.
Tammany's put us all in the same place. You want to get o
It don't matter to me. I got enemies outside, enemies in can move on me anytime. You could drop me before I get to
I don't want to lose you so easy. You'll never get past t you come with the Dead Rabbits.
You'd lay aside what's between us?
I'm not forgetting where I put it.
If you do, I'll remind you. (he turns, leaves)
What's your call, Bill?
I'm considering where's my better chance. He walks to the doors. The Rabbits guarding it don't make it himself and strides out into the street.

Bill walks alone toward the Native/militia lines. From inside... from every window ... the Dead Rabbits wat The sun is high, but the street is eerily quiet. There ar of battle, but here there is only the sound of distant, u conversation between Bill, the Militia Commander and some Amsterdam WATCHES intently. The Butcher and the Militia Commander argue, but we still they're saying. There is still no sound... ... until, SUDDENLY, we see the Militia Commander's face. with surprise as we HEAR the thunderclap of a SHOT. Bill the Butcher has just gutshot the Militia Commander. As if the shot were a signal, the Natives TURN on the mil hellish, close-quarter combat. Guns fired inches from ene been allies. Knives, swords, bludgeons, kids with dead-ra women with hob-nailed wooden planks, attacking better-arm stunned soldiers. Bill the Butcher falls back toward the Armory, the Native Inside the Armory, Amsterdam turns to his own greatly dim

Go ahead them, give them cover! Give them some damn cover The Rabbits are so stunned to be fighting on the same sid enemies that, even with Amsterdam's order, no one makes a Amsterdam who FIRES the first shots. And that unleashes a from the Armory... ... toward the militia. The Butcher and the Natives are closer to the Armory now. doors start to open... ... when a MILITIA LIEUTENANT SIGNALS ... ... and MILITIA on the surrounding roofs, waiting for thi suddenly open fire...on the Natives below and on the Rabb of the armory. Many drop in the street and fall from the ... as the Armory doors SWING WIDE to admit the Natives. stagger inside, the Rabbits start to close the doors. Som down by the fire from the rooftops. Other Natives never m doors. And a few are shot... ... when the doors close before they can get through.
The Dead Rabbits keep firing, but they have sustained gra Butcher looks around at the Natives who have made it insi has perhaps one-quarter of his original strength.
Well, it seems like between us we got two mobs that might
Whose gang might it be?
Not William Tweed's. Jimmy Spoils and a crew of Natives PUSH a cannon toward t Armory.
Which way you pointing that?
Any way you say. One direction could let us out, the othe in.
They got to come in if we're going to fight them.

Who do you want to fight, Bill? Amsterdam MOTIONS toward the rear wall and Jimmy swings t Everything surrounding them is MOVEMENT and COMMOTION as members of both gangs TAKE whatever weapons they can carr stockpile... ... and Jenny steps forward with a torch, LIGHTING the fu cannon... ... which ROARS and BLOWS a huge hole in the rear wall of

(to Bill the Butcher) See you in the street. The gang members RUSH for the opening, carrying whatever Outside, the MILITIA LIEUTENANT hears the cannon blast... to the front of the building... and SIGNALS for a frontal Armory. HIGH ANGLE FROM ABOVE, CAMERA MOVING as the militia CHARG them forward, then moving ahead to the Armory ... SHOOTING straight down inside (no roof or ceiling) as through the still-smoldering hole in the wall ... ... and drop twenty feet to an alley below... ... where militia on the roof try to pick them off. As th closer from the front, gang defenses start to fall back i Everyone wants to get through that hole. Amsterdam, Jenny, Jimmy Spoils and some of the other gang carrying TORCHES. Jenny HANDS a torch to the Butcher. Ams them all toward the back of the Armory. But he stays behind. Just for a moment. He BENDS over the Johnny Sirocco, ARRANGES it, folding JOHNNY'S HANDS acros

You'll have a warrior's funeral anyway, John. He STANDS and RUNS for the hole in the wall, where Jenny stand waiting. He TURNS, takes a last look inside the Armory. The militi DOWN the front doors. Then he raises his TORCH over his h it through the air. Jenny and the others do the same. His single torch BLAZES a path of light across the screen JOINING it, make a fiery CONSTELLATION.

head_text.subj: EXT. REAR OF ARMORY/STREETS BEHIND ARMORY DAY

text: As Jenny, Jimmy Spoils, Bill the Butcher and Amsterdam HU hole into the alley below... ... and start to run through the withering GUNFIRE of the roof... ... getting away... just barely away. As Jenny runs, her swag drops and FALLS from under her cl to pick it up but Amsterdam PULLS her on.... ... and just away from the titanic EXPLOSION of the Armor throws some of the militia from their perches on the roof fountain of FLAME and RUBBLE high into the sky. It is VOL brilliance and intensity. The sky turns BLACK with powder with flame. In the small streets BEHIND THE ARMORY, many gang members debris or burned by FIREBALLS breaking off from the centr The Armory is gone. Much of the surrounding area is gone On the ground, everything is smoke, flame, dirt, death, c everywhere. Gang members and kids running all over, despe like the last day of mankind on earth. Bill the Butcher HELPS a couple of fallen Natives, then S smoke and flame and storm of ash ... Amsterdam. Coming towards him.
We're finished, all of us.
But you and me ain't settled.
We got the same now, a full share of nothing. There's not There's nothing left. Amsterdam takes a weapon from his pocket, OPENS it for th it is the pirate's knife which the Butcher used to kill P
Then let's start over. Bill the Butcher looks tired, sorrowful. He BURIES his fa arms. And for a moment we think he has given everything u MOVES toward him, throu
